content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												Good game with a flavor of Harvest Moon in it.  The game isnt deep in the combat sense but for what if offers is a great game.  I would recommend getting this when it is under $10.  The time sink in the game is easily 50+ hours because of the several new game modes that become available after you beat the game the first time.The game works every day you have several turns to do stuff and those are devided in selling items at the shop, buying items around town and visting town, and dungeon crawling for items to sell or use on the your heroes you play as.  Every week you have to pay a debt so you do not get a game over.  After several weeks of paying the debt you win!  And then the game opens up lots of stuff for you to do and keep on farming and grinding.PROS-Great time sink to fix that Harvest Moon guilty pleasure-Boss fights have mechanics and make the game not just a pure hac and slash-One the game is beat you have lots of options to keep playing or just be satisfied with another game down-For what is offered in the game is greatNegatives-Not to crazy on the character development

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale is cute and fun game. For me, this game is perfect collection of genres, combining a shop sim, a dungeon crawling action RPG, and visual novel style segments all into one game.The basics of the plot is that you are Recette, a young girl who's adventurer father disappears and leave behind a crippling debt that threatens to take away your home and everything in it. So you along with Tear, the fairy loan officer responsible for you paying the debt back, open an item shop. From there on out you can go out into town to buy stock and meet people, or hire an adventurer to bring items you can sell back from dungeons.The difficulty curve can be intense, with your payments going up exponentially. However, I would consider this to be a medium difficulty game. Neither the shop segments or the dungeons are too difficult, though they still can be hard and tricky.There are 8 adventurers that you can unlock over the course of the game for the dungeon portions and each has a unique combat style and abilities from one another, so there is plenty of variety whether you want to change things up or find a style that suits you best. There are also 6 dungeons, each one harder that the first but providing better drops progressively.The plot is presented in very cute visual novel style segments and is quite light and relaxed despite the goal to pay off an ever increasing debt. I find it fits the medium difficulty game play segments very well. To trigger most of the story segments requires you to leave the shop and waste a chunk of your time, but the characters are all unique, fun and quirky. It's also the only way to unlock some of your potential adventures, so it can be worth your time.All in all, I love this game. It's not to difficult to pick up and has a lot of content available so you can keep playing for hours.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												Recettear is a perfect storm of cuteness and capitalism, all wrapped up nicely in Japanese paper.  I know a few people with this game, and wel all play it differently.  I tend to focus solely on my storefront, one person I know spends all his time in dungeons, and yet another has something of a 60/40 mix between the two, leaning towards dungeon play.One of the things that makes Recettear such a great game is that all of these playstyles are completely viable.  The item shop really is yours, and you can do whatever you want with it, provided you make the proper payments on time.  Want to make a dark cabal, where ancient artifacts of mystical Lovecraftian horrors are traded behind closed doors?  Done.  Want to make a homemaker's paradise, with clothes and food and tools as far as the eye can see?  Easy enough to put together.  Or maybe you'd rather outfit adventurers to go expeditioning with you, offering them low prices on advanced gear?  Great idea.Recettear manages to give you more empowerment than most store simulation games, and that's only half of what it is.  Its dungeon-crawling aspect is, to me, a little contrived, and not as well executed as, say, Torchlight, but it certainly gets the job done, and if loot gives you joy, you'll probably find the later dungeons particularly pleasing anyway.And let's not gloss over the art and writing, both of which are some of the cutest available, anywhere, ever.  This is the game that coined the word "Yepperoni" which is probably the most important English word I know.  If you're not into cute stuff, however, or you think it's lame or contrived, you really should pass, because this game is cute before it's anything else.To nitpick, my one gripe is that this game does not support any full-screen resolutions in widescreen aspect ratios, but that's essentially to be expected of doujinsoft.  For me, however, the game is nearly perfect in all other regards, so in my eyes it is all but a must-play.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												I'd say the 82% Metascore is pretty spot on. A lot of fun, and sometimes you can just pick it up and sink a couple hours into it without feeling overly committed. Not the absolute best game of all time, but certainly has its charm.I'd recommend it to anyone who enjoys light simulation-RPGs in the style of Rune Factory; the dungeons are pretty simplistic but still good cheap fun. I'm also impressed with the localization job; a lot of the Japanese dialogue is almost spot on for the first line of text.Suggestions to draw out the enjoyment factor are:- Go to a dungeon at least twice per game week, and clear out a 5 level stretch. Only playing the shop aspect can get really repetitive without a break, and you're really going to be missing out on a lot of gameplay aspects if you don't do both.- Don't read too many FAQs and guides unless you're stuck; the programming isn't the most sophisticated and it's really easy to find the tricks and exploits that make the game a cakewalk. Try to find the tricks yourself, it's a major part of the fun.- Plug in a PS3/XBOX/PC USB game controller if you have one, it'll make the dungeons more relaxing and fun instead of annoying- Once you get a good idea of how the game works, try to beat the game in a single "loop". (Your save games will indicate how many times you continued after a game over or started a new game plus over a previous game.)Have fun, and don't let Euria into your shop!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												Recettear.. I wasn't sure what to expect when I saw this game, but I bought it because it was on sale and seemed moderatly interesting.. How wrong I was. Monderatly? This game is amazing! It's such a refershing change on typical RPG's! Owning your own store is pretty interesting, you have to keep earning an increased amount every week or you're screwed. Seems boring right? But somehow bartering prices for both purchases and sales with your customers is rather exciting (Except when a certain little girl tries shopping). As you progress in levels, new features are added like taking orders for item.For item gathering itself, you have the option to buy items from the Market and Mechants Guild, aswell as items customers are trying to sell. However the best and obviously most fun option, is hiring an adventurer and going out to dungeons to slay monsters, find chests and collecting items to sell in your shop. The combat system is EXTREMELY basic, you have your movement keys, an attack button and a special attack button.. Thats it, but somehow the combat still feels great and rewarding. While you start out with a single adventurer, you eventually lock others of a different class, each with their own moves and differences. Whats cooler is these aren't just random characters you fight with, each one of them has their own personality. You see them at the town center, pub, church or even shopping inside your store. And these adventurers aren't the only ones with personalitys! There are quite a few characters in the game, and while not all of them have names, you can see a general personality and gain familiarity with them. The random man will typically buy goods for this much, while the little girl won't do it for more than this. You can see aspects of their daily lives in town, and with the familiarity you can actually get feelings towards people shopping, good or bad! You'll know this person likes to haggle, these people are cheap or these people will accept higher prices.This is a great twist, and while the idea of it might not sound great, it is. It brings a fresh and great idea with excellent exacution, with an art style that never goes bad! Even $20 is a great price for a game!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												There's already a slew of other reviews telling you this is a good game. They probably either focus a lot or not enough about the sum of all parts. I'm going to only explain why I personally think this game turns from good into great.Dungeon crawling is considered awful and/or boring for most people I know. They like shooters or some sports games. A few actually like RPGs. And Recettear is definitely a good RPG with a fair amount of simplistic dungeon crawling. It's also interesting how its simplicity aids the game's concept, because if you're anything like me you'll actually like more the character's shop management than going into dungeons to sell the crap out of what a monster unwittingly thought was fun to be lugging around for no reason.In other words, I think the whole shop management deal is what makes Recettear a good game. If I were to judge it solely on the dungeon crawler aspect I'd tell you that I've played many considerably better dungeon crawlers. Heck, I'd even tell you that Rogue and a great part of it's infinite spawn of clones and wannabes is a better game on dungeon crawling alone. But the shop management, from what goods you'll display on that particular day, the kind of display furniture you're using, and even the little feeling of having sold the junk that some monster considered valuable enough to carry for astronomical values to the masses of curious customers... is only 14.99 away from you.Let me sweeten the deal here. Carpe Fulgur, the publisher, is one of those that normally has its games featured on discounts on Steam. It's not uncommon to drop around 60% of the price from time to time. And you can't say that the cute-as-kittens-and-fun-as-(games I suppose?) protagonist and its struggles don't capture your heart to the point where you will want to help her get the funds for the next loan she NEEDS to pay, and then see the story evolve gradually with the other characters she gets involved with.Also, you get to see the witty translation of whatever the original game had in its original language of (I assume) Japanese into "Capitalism, HO!", Recette's happy money-making battlecry, among other instant classics. There's plenty of humour to read in the dialogues, and sometimes you'll think that you're also paying for a comic book with all of the grins, smiles and even laughter that you'll find yourself performing. Do you still think 14,99 is too much?There's also a demo for the unbelieving masses to try. That's, of course, the safe approach. Try that demo and you'll see you'll want to buy the full game. If you're worried about the investment, wait for the sales, often Midweek on Steam, or maybe even the big summer or winter sales. You can thank yourself for the investment later.

												An item shop economy simulator combined with a Zelda-style top-down action. Trying to balance your daily schedule, interacting with townsfolk and trying to accommodate customers' whims is interesting at first.However, once you learn the simple hidden rules that govern the customers, you'll be swimming in cash and will blaze through the story in no time. That leaves the action, which really isn't that interesting unless you like mindless grinding.But if you prefer the action, you probably would like Chantelise better; It's made by the same studio and uses the same engine.

												The only knock on this game is that the difficulty progresses as a misleadingly steep pace.That said, the game does handle that well enough inside of itself- you can take what you learned (and earned)- into future attempts.The characters are cute, the gameplay, while a little rough around the edges is perfectly playable and most importantly fun. content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
 The Oliver Review  The Story The story is a main part of this game. It allows the player to fully immerse themselves in the events of the game. Recettear does a phenomenal job at this task. I found the story incredibly enjoyable. I felt the emotions alongside the characters. The principle may seem basic, but if you really connect to the characters, this will be an experience you will treasure for al of your gaming life. The Gameplay The gameplay is amazing on its own. The active task of setting up a shop and selling your items is an invigorating feeling. Starting from the cheaper items, and steadily working your way up to the more expensive assortment of goods. It gives you a feeling of accomplishment that you have a hard time getting out of most other games. With the increasing difficulty of the game, it has both a challenging and a relaxed atmosphere. The other aspect is the Dungeons. You send out a hero you get from interacting with them either around town, or in your shop. In these dungeons, the more expensive variety of loot lies deep in them. The gameplay in these areas is a bit faster paced, but overall the game tends to be patient and relaxed.  The Personality The game is very relaxed. It does take it slow throughout the whole experience. The games failure  mechanic is that you start from the beginning, only you still have your levels and items. The game has a feeling of accomplishment with everything in it. Whether it be gaining a level, or selling that expensive item. This game makes you work for it, but still guides you along the path enough so you don't feel lost. The Rating In The Oliver Rating system, this game has the Oliver Rating of 4.7/5 This game has my recommendation to  Play and Replay

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												TLDR version: Doesn't exactly reinvent the wheel and can get repetitive but for any fans of JRPGs or dungeon crawlers, this little gem does more than enough to justify the modest asking price (Pssst this game goes on sale often)Story and Characters: You play as Recette, a cheerful naive and only somewhat annoying little girl whos carefree life gets shattered when her father disappears and she's left to pay his debts to a fairy named Tear. Your goal is to open the store her father left in order to pay off weekly payments to Tear or lose your home. It's not exactly on the level of the Count of Monte Cristo but for a cutesy game like this it's all the motivation you'll need.The characters are pretty simple anime cliche, but most are charming in their own right. Tear makes a great straight man to Recette's bubble-headed obliviousness. Charme the thief is a likeable rogue and kind of like a big sister to our lead. That being said a number of characters are very one note and that note is typically "rude and nasty for no particular reason". Still, you have the option to skip any dialog and if your anything like me your finger will fly to that escape key any time you see that irritating rich girl.Graphics: The visuals are decent, they do their job expressing the world but they aren't very inspired. Customizing your store is the most visually impressive part of the game. Expect to see a lot of brown and gray dungeons copy pasted almost to the point of frustration. Closeups during dialog convey a great sense of personality but the actual models only look OK. Animation is nice and smooth and the frame rate is pleasingly consistent throughout which is all that really matters in a budget title like this.Audio: Voice acting is all in Japanese and it's cute, if a bit unnecessary with dialog being mostly text. The music isn't really worth noting. It's mostly cute and bouncy MIDI tunes that loop over and over. By far the most awful thing about the game is the ear-bleeding harmonica track that plays when walking around your store. It didn't take long for me to mute the music, and you likely will too.Gameplay: This dungeon crawling ARPG has just enough twists to the classic formula to really make it addictive. Your time will be split between selling items in your store and running down to the dungeon hoping to find loot to sell at said store. It's easy to assume the selling part would be the weakest but it's amazing how nail-biting selling stuff can be when your next payment is due tomorrow and your still 5000 short. Do you jack up your prices and risk a customer walking out on you? Will anybody buy that really expensive item you absolutely need to sell to make your payment? How much is too much for a chocolate bar? This game manages to make such a mundane idea quite exciting.The dungeon crawling is also quite fun if a little basic. You start with just one swordsman to dungeon dive with but you later unlock a quick thief, a glass cannon mage, etc. They all have different items to equip, different abilites, and different special attacks so there's enough variety to keep it fresh.  Enemies are generic looking but each one has different attacks and movement patterns, such as knights being able to protect themselves with shields or the winged eyeballs shooting lasers at you. The only real issue I have with the controls is the momentum characters gain while moving seems a bit too much. I found myself walking straight into enemies I meant to avoid or having a hard time wheeling myself around to hit their weak spots before they moved.What really stands out is the way RPG conventions are subverted. This might be the only RPG I've ever played where my characters level didn't matter to me. After all, the game measures your progression almost completely with money, so while filling your merchant EXP bar grants new perks to make the money pile up, the combat EXP isn't nearly as important. Sure tougher dungeons usually have better loot but the only reason I was happy I leveled was for the HP refill so I didn't have to use any of the healing items I found. I didn't really know or care what level my hero was as long as I could carry out a huge bag of loot.All in all, Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale is a fun, cute and simple ARPG well worth your time and money. It's not for everyone and it's not exactly the kind of game that will leave you glued to the edge of your seat but it has novel gameplay and lots of charm sure to appeal to the RPG crowd looking for something different. And hey, if you enjoy story mode and you can play challenge mode and fulfill your fantasy of fighting your ever-growing debt until the massive payments force you into bankruptcy! Sorry, too real?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												I picked this up in a bundle on steam a couple of years ago. While this game wasn't the reason I purchased the bundle, I ended up spending more time on it than I did any other game in it. The game has a wonderfully cheeky sense of humor as you are thrust into a viciously capitalistic society. Be careful, this game gets pretty hard pretty quickly, but after losing there is a sort of "new game plus" where you get to retain all of the stuff you had previously, which makes it easier. It's easy enough to beat on your second loop through the game, but trying to beat it without ever getting a game over is much more of a challenge.There's also a whole top-down action-adventure game embedded within the capitalism simulator, which is pretty fun. It's not as good as other games of its type, but for a part of an otherwise solid game, it does its job well.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2012
												Sure, the game starts off as your typical Japanese cutesy thing. But soon enough, you realise things. For one, customers are not your friends. You won't win any prizes for selling at cost price. You go higher... a hundred and five... hundred and ten... hundred and fifteen... High, but not high enough to make them suspicious.You'll learn how they act, what they'll spend, and go in for the kill.Adventurers will be your tools. Cavediving may seem like an extra, but it's the only way of finding some of the most profitable treasures. You don't wanna buy from a wholesale seller or such - after all, that means less profit. You'll give them some equipment, maybe some food, and then hope they come back alive. Perhaps they will. After all, you play them. But if they die, you can only take a few things with you back up. Maybe you'll sell something to them, later, when they come browsing. At just under 150% of it's base price.Underneath that cute exterior is a game about making money.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2011
												Unlike other  typical jRPG our hero (in this case heroine) is not warrior, nor a mage, nor an archer, but a simple merchant. Recette (Thats her name) isn't going to save a world, she just need to repay debt taken by her father. The idea is simple. In order to achive that, she (with a help of loan shark Tear) opens a item shop.Now the fun part begins.Main key is to sit in your shop and sell items (just like merchants in other jrpgs). But where will u get them? You can stack yourself at merchant guild or hire an adventurer As the game progress, we need to deal with: getting ordered items on time, watching over market prices and we cannot forget about stacking up our shop, haggleing + we have to repay Tear exact amount that our father borrowed b4 he left home. Getting good schedule and having luck on market makes this game really entertaining. All of this makes this game a nice alternative for typical jRPGs.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2010
												On the surface, it's just a cutesy indie Japanese item shop simulator, but what surprised me was the amount of depth and polish that went into the game's RPG and dungeon-crawling aspects.  The gameplay is very open-ended -- you're free to spend all your time playing with the economic side of things, or (if you're like me) you can focus on leveling up your various adventurers and slashing/blowing up/punching/shooting all sorts of baddies and neglect your shop entirely.  The story is pretty cheesy, but the interactions between characters are always entertaining.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												I got this in a bundle recently and didn't really expect much from it. It's actually a really fun game that is done very well. The graphics aren't amazing, but they're definitely acceptable, and the game has a lot of humor and good design. It's kind of like a mix between Animal Crossing, Torchlight/Diablo, and that Lemonade Stand game you might have played in elementary school. Anyways, it's an interesting blend of genres to me, and the game has a lot of personality. I've found myself playing it for hours a day the last few days. I'm not sure I'd strongly recommend it at the suggested $20 price point, but if you can find it on sale, pick it up. Also, you might want to check out the demo. You might find yourself pulled in by its charm like I have.Also, disregard the time played on here. I played this game mostly in offline mode, and I guess Steam doesn't calculate that playing time. I've played it for at least a dozen hours or so.

Posted: December 27, 2013
												A JRPG with overall generic characters and a plot that has generic daddy left me so i must do grown up things since hes ♥♥♥♥ed me over majorly even though im 10ish year old girl. Now the amazing thing is after playing this game for two hours i realized something, i was having fun. My cold cynical heart actually had a pulse when i made this realization that i was playing a game and enjoying it throughly. The games mixture of simple combat and simple store mechanics entised me to play on. Though the combat is lacking to simply push button 1 to light attack and button 2 to special attack it had a nice retro top down zelda feel to it. Not saying its perfect since the basic attack randomly crits enemys (should have a pattern or be user determined when activated -_-) but overall fun. Then theres the other core aspect of the game where you are running a store, not the most exciting thing in the world but lemonade tycoon feel. Sure you can sell stuff safely at 120% of the original price but trying to sqeeuze out that extra 1-2% out of your souless buyers feels good. Not a great game but id say a nice game to kill the time or have as babies "My first JRPG".

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												I'd say the 82% Metascore is pretty spot on. A lot of fun, and sometimes you can just pick it up and sink a couple hours into it without feeling overly committed. Not the absolute best game of all time, but certainly has its charm.I'd recommend it to anyone who enjoys light simulation-RPGs in the style of Rune Factory; the dungeons are pretty simplistic but still good cheap fun. I'm also impressed with the localization job; a lot of the Japanese dialogue is almost spot on for the first line of text.Suggestions to draw out the enjoyment factor are:- Go to a dungeon at least twice per game week, and clear out a 5 level stretch. Only playing the shop aspect can get really repetitive without a break, and you're really going to be missing out on a lot of gameplay aspects if you don't do both.- Don't read too many FAQs and guides unless you're stuck; the programming isn't the most sophisticated and it's really easy to find the tricks and exploits that make the game a cakewalk. Try to find the tricks yourself, it's a major part of the fun.- Plug in a PS3/XBOX/PC USB game controller if you have one, it'll make the dungeons more relaxing and fun instead of annoying- Once you get a good idea of how the game works, try to beat the game in a single "loop". (Your save games will indicate how many times you continued after a game over or started a new game plus over a previous game.)Have fun, and don't let Euria into your shop!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												Recettear.. I wasn't sure what to expect when I saw this game, but I bought it because it was on sale and seemed moderatly interesting.. How wrong I was. Monderatly? This game is amazing! It's such a refershing change on typical RPG's! Owning your own store is pretty interesting, you have to keep earning an increased amount every week or you're screwed. Seems boring right? But somehow bartering prices for both purchases and sales with your customers is rather exciting (Except when a certain little girl tries shopping). As you progress in levels, new features are added like taking orders for item.For item gathering itself, you have the option to buy items from the Market and Mechants Guild, aswell as items customers are trying to sell. However the best and obviously most fun option, is hiring an adventurer and going out to dungeons to slay monsters, find chests and collecting items to sell in your shop. The combat system is EXTREMELY basic, you have your movement keys, an attack button and a special attack button.. Thats it, but somehow the combat still feels great and rewarding. While you start out with a single adventurer, you eventually lock others of a different class, each with their own moves and differences. Whats cooler is these aren't just random characters you fight with, each one of them has their own personality. You see them at the town center, pub, church or even shopping inside your store. And these adventurers aren't the only ones with personalitys! There are quite a few characters in the game, and while not all of them have names, you can see a general personality and gain familiarity with them. The random man will typically buy goods for this much, while the little girl won't do it for more than this. You can see aspects of their daily lives in town, and with the familiarity you can actually get feelings towards people shopping, good or bad! You'll know this person likes to haggle, these people are cheap or these people will accept higher prices.This is a great twist, and while the idea of it might not sound great, it is. It brings a fresh and great idea with excellent exacution, with an art style that never goes bad! Even $20 is a great price for a game!

content:
Posted: December 25, 2010
												A friend asked me, "HOW IS THIS GAME SO FUN?" I replied, "It is kind of impressive how fun it is being an NPC, isn't it?" And it is. You can't really summarize this game; it's got too many great things going for it, and attempts to do so generally result in disbelief that a game like that can be as entertaining as claimed.The game's about running an item shop. Initially you have to pay off your debt but once that's done you enter "Endless Mode" and can enjoy being a merchant (and also running through dungeons to get loot!) to your heart's content. Don't be disheartened by failure; even if you fail to pay off your debt, you'll still get a second chance.Good luck getting 100% completion; the post-endgame content is ridiculously beefy, and filling out your item encyclopedia requires at least six or seven playthroughs. And even when you've got that sorted out, you STILL have Endless Mode to challenge yourself with.Also it's an indie title, if you like that sort of thing.

Posted: December 6, 2010
												Different is the name of the game with this quirky little RPG/Economy game, Recttear.  Somewhat difficult to explain, Recttear must be experienced to be fully understood. You own a store and hire characters to go down into the dungeon to fetch you treasure to sell. The game is split into those two basic parts; selling the goods at the store, and hunting in the darkened dungeon to find lost treasures. This two part approach worked for me as I found myself playing to get my store awesome and my heroes to be ultra-awesome. Recttear is a bit dated and the story is basically devoid, but the game is very fun and highly addictive. You’ll find yourself mumbling just one more level often as you tack on the hours in this enjoyable game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												I love this game. The art style is cute and the game mechanics are simple. The game is a little out of the box for an RPG. It is both a sim game as well as a dungeon crawling game instead of just the latter. You are an adorable (yet annoying and too cheerfully trusting girl) that gets left with her dad's massive debt. She is guided by her fairy (the very serious loanshark) to open up an item shop to help repay it. Now the game is simple to understand. You have the day broken up into four parts. You decide what you want to do for the day whether it be shopping for items to stock, adventuring with a hero for loot, or stocking you store and opening it to the public. Ultimately it's all about the money. Or pix I should say. One part of the gameplay is the shop. You end up haggling with customers to get the best price and stocking it to attract the most customers. The second form of gameplay is adventuring with the hero. This is where the "little out of the box" ends. This is your typical RPG where you go around killing monsters picking up loot and equipping or using items. Definitely appreciate this portion of the game because when I get bored of selling things to people (or running low on items AND being bored) I get to change the scenery in a sense. It's really a great game with just enough to keep you going.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												Recettear takes an interesting concept (running an rpg-world item shop) and makes an entertaining game out of it. Charming is a good way to describe the game itself - the characters are adorable and endearing, the gameplay is like a neat mini-game, and the overall atmosphere is comfortable and relaxing. Recettear struggles to really excel in any area and the gameplay becomes repetitive, but it never loses that sense of charm and is a fun game to play once and then re-install every once in a while for a bit of relaxing capitalism.If you aren't fan of any jrpg's or just don't find the concept entertaining you won't miss much by skipping this game, but if you have any fond memories of jrpg's this is a great game to pick up for some casual fun. Capitalism ho!

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												The game is fun and offers some stratagy based money management as well as requiring a bit of luck.In standard new game there are only 2 dungeons, one is basically a tutorial dungeon with not a lot to offer the other is a 3 part dungeon with a 4th area allowing you to fight just the bosses over and over again.Early in the game dungeon crawling is a must to gain pix, however later on, for me it was after just the 2nd week, it no longer seems really helpful.Often times townspeople will come in selling an item and then before the time segment is even over will buy it right back. One of the best ways to make money is buying for 30% and reselling for 130%.One of the best items to stock up I found was weapons, in later weeks they get boosts in value and can be sold for as much as 300% base. For me the last 3 days all weapons were increased in value, not sure if it was luck or game mechanics, but in the last 3 days alone I amassed over 300k pix.The game does have NG+ as well as a survival mode, but for the most part there doesn't really seem to be a whole lot of replay value after you intitally beat it.I bought it on sale for 9.99, not 100% I got my moneys worth, but it was definitely a fun game. I have a total of around 7 hours in the game including offline time, and that's about the amount of time it took me to beat it with having to start over once. I'd recommend buying it, but definitely on sale for 9.99 or less simply because of how short the game is, and how little replay value it offers in my opinion.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2013
												Recettear is very much a delightful game that will keep you entertained for roughly 10 hours depending on how you play (for one play through). The game revolves around running an item shop, and the challenges that brings. It also has adventure opportunities where you can play in some very basic Legend of Zelda-like game play (better example would be Neutopia on the TurboGraphics 16) from the original NES days, although with better graphics, in order to acquire rare and cool items for sale. There is a ton of content it seems for this game, but most of it you will likely not use during the main course of the game. The reason being that taking advantage of such usually requires risk, and since you have to meet monetary goals within a certain amount of time in the main story, you may choose to go a safer route. Nevertheless, this game offers quite the charming gameplay despite it being repetative at times. I highly recommend this game if you can manage to get it for $10 or less. If not, then it really depends on how many hours of gameplay you expect at minimum to get per dollar you spend.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												Recettear - if I had to sum it up in a couple of words, I would describe it as a concept that should fail, but doesn't. The gameplay is repetitive, the dungeon crawling requires excessive amounts of grinding to gather materials, and the light-novel/anime style is probably a turn off to some.In practice though, Recettear is an unexpected hit, and a real hidden gem. Recette herself is adorable and everything she does just makes players want to love her more. The concept is fresh and unusual: run your very own item shop, pay off the loan-shark fairy! Play smart, watch for special deals, buy low and sell high to try to maximize your profit! Balance between the general approval of your customers and your profit margins to maximize revenue!Not only is the concept of running one's own item shop interesting on its own right, but the game can be unexpectedly challenging. Many players fail to pay off the debt and have to use the game's "mulligan" system to complete it (or mulligan by save-scumming) because they got too greedy seeing a deadline approaching, or because they failed to account for a potential drop in an item's value.Earlier I mentioned that the dungeoneering is pretty bad, and that's true to an extent: there aren't many dungeons, the loot is sporadic and it can take lots of materials to make just one item, and the combat is perhaps too simplistic. Yet there are a slew of characters available, each with their own quirks, and exploring the dungeons can help reward a player with new characters, thereby increasing the amount of interactions.Speaking of interactions, these characters interact very frequently. The writing is light-hearted, and conversations do not feel like they drag on for any absurd length of time (they can all be skipped as well). Yet at the same time, there are little mysteries about the world that make players want to know more about the world and the people in it. The characters, all in all, are a huge part of what gives Recettear its charm.Sure, there are a lot of fridge logic moments - areas where a player just wants to say "hey, that shouldn't happen because..." but for the most part, none of these obstruct the game's flow.Overall, Recettear is a charming little adventure. It's not the most adrenaline pumping adventure, but one can't help but admire how well put together and cute the game is. I highly recommend it for anyone looking for something light-hearted yet difficult enough to warrant paying attention to.So go - with a little luck, hard work, and the spirit of capitalism, how hard can it be to exploit your friends and pay back the loan-shark fairy?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												Recettear is a perfect storm of cuteness and capitalism, all wrapped up nicely in Japanese paper.  I know a few people with this game, and wel all play it differently.  I tend to focus solely on my storefront, one person I know spends all his time in dungeons, and yet another has something of a 60/40 mix between the two, leaning towards dungeon play.One of the things that makes Recettear such a great game is that all of these playstyles are completely viable.  The item shop really is yours, and you can do whatever you want with it, provided you make the proper payments on time.  Want to make a dark cabal, where ancient artifacts of mystical Lovecraftian horrors are traded behind closed doors?  Done.  Want to make a homemaker's paradise, with clothes and food and tools as far as the eye can see?  Easy enough to put together.  Or maybe you'd rather outfit adventurers to go expeditioning with you, offering them low prices on advanced gear?  Great idea.Recettear manages to give you more empowerment than most store simulation games, and that's only half of what it is.  Its dungeon-crawling aspect is, to me, a little contrived, and not as well executed as, say, Torchlight, but it certainly gets the job done, and if loot gives you joy, you'll probably find the later dungeons particularly pleasing anyway.And let's not gloss over the art and writing, both of which are some of the cutest available, anywhere, ever.  This is the game that coined the word "Yepperoni" which is probably the most important English word I know.  If you're not into cute stuff, however, or you think it's lame or contrived, you really should pass, because this game is cute before it's anything else.To nitpick, my one gripe is that this game does not support any full-screen resolutions in widescreen aspect ratios, but that's essentially to be expected of doujinsoft.  For me, however, the game is nearly perfect in all other regards, so in my eyes it is all but a must-play.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												How to haggle like a pro.Usually, the hero of a video game is the representation of what society views as 'strong, courageous and tough'. This is why male heroes make up such a collectively large proporition of protagonists in video games and all mediums of entertainment; books, movies, lolcat memes (not the norm) are all forms of entertainment that attribute widely to the popular - and I emphasize popular- social stigma of society. Examples are here:Fifty Shades of Grey: Super hot stuffWhite men can't jump: Self explanatoryLocat memes: Desire to anthropomorphize ourselves into kittens.Now let's focus on Recettear again.Let's say 'hypothetically' that Recettear is 'different' from the norm. Instead of a strong male lead, you now have a female lead who starts off relatively inept (Not an opinion against females, just what the character starts off as). Her only benefits being that she doesn't need to eat, or atleast from what we can see, and that she can follow a schedule better than any student or adult in the known world. Also, she's an anime girl: the truest and strongest form of feminist pro propagandanism. So what gives?How are we supposed to connect with this game if there isn't anything remarkably 'interesting' to connect to?Well, that's the essential difference in video games; it doesn't need to because video games aren't all words or film.Here's why:Recettear is absolutely blossoming in charm from its art style (animesque) to the gameplay (finances 101). It's a mix mash of japanese tropes/culture,dungeon crawling and finances. Though, I wouldn't go so far as call it an RPG because it's remarkably hard to connect with the main character, but it serves well in its main drive of gameplay; the flesh of the gameplay is the retrieving and selling of products with a hint of dungeonesque elements, specifically you need to get sellable materials from the dungeon to sell. And boy, you want to sell, sell and sell because debts in game come in fast. In fact, never has procrastination on debt lead to such dire consequences where a little a girl gets evicted from her home to the doghouse, though if that's your thing...However, in the end, the frantic nature of gameplay makes each decision a calculated decision to maximize profits from retrieving and selling. Thus, you will want to haggle everyone despite your best conciousness; a little old lady, how nice! Sell the bagel at 500% mark up. It's a deal she can't refuse, literally! (Starving old lady)It's a game that will teach you how exploitative you can be and you know what? That's the best form of video game.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2012
												Most unexpected fun you can ever have out of a shop-sim. Recettear is about management, of both time and resources, and it's good at that. It also has an overview-grid action RPG-mechanic that isn't as interesting and at times gets pretty tedious, but it's still head and shoulders above average. The real draw here is the store. Not only is the shopkeeping gameplay plenty addictive for its beautiful aesthetics and atmosphere, but it's also very understanding about difficulty. Every time you happen to fail your quest to save your store from bankruptcy, you get to keep your experience points from the previous go and the next attempt will be a whole lot easier afterwards. You simply cannot fail if you just keep failing long enough, so experts will complete the game in one go, while beginners will slowly learn by getting stronger from failure. A very balanced system for all kinds.Plenty of replayability if you know what's good for you. Capitalism, ho!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												A surprisingly addictive game!  This Japanese Indie (doujin) game has been translated very well and with loving detail.  The voices are still in Japanese (left unsubbed, but their vocals basically match the dialogue text anyway), but it doesn't take away from enjoying the game at all.  The item shop mechanics are simple but engaging, with challenges such as a change in trends and item value during certain times.  The dungeon crawler mechanics are also simple, with a top-down view of your character as you explore and defeat monsters.  There is also a way to fuse items in order to sell things that aren't regularly offered in stores.  Graphics aren't glamorous but acceptable, which is great for my laptop (not optimized for gaming)!The game is, overall, fairly simple and not very complicated.  I think it's perfect for it's price and quality.  There is even a replay value to it for all the completionists out there.  That's more than I can say about some full-priced games in the market!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												A lovely doujin game, part strategy, part tycoon, part dungeon crawler. You play as Recette Lemongrass, a clueless young girl who is given 4 weeks to pay off a loan her father took and disappeared with. You take over his shop where you can buy and sell various items to earn money. You can buy and resell items from the marketplace, or from people or you can go and do dungeons to get items without having to pay for them.  The idea of the game is to earn a profit while keeping your customers happy so that they will return for repeat business. The game gradually introduces gameplay mechanics until you realize that there is a fairly deep game hiding behind the cute exterior presentation. Don't be put off by the Japanese style, the Anime look or the fact that it's made in Flash. This is the reason we play games... to discover new and wonderful experiences that can be had through this medium. I thought it was worth full price, but it's definitely worth getting in a sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2012
												Sure, the game starts off as your typical Japanese cutesy thing. But soon enough, you realise things. For one, customers are not your friends. You won't win any prizes for selling at cost price. You go higher... a hundred and five... hundred and ten... hundred and fifteen... High, but not high enough to make them suspicious.You'll learn how they act, what they'll spend, and go in for the kill.Adventurers will be your tools. Cavediving may seem like an extra, but it's the only way of finding some of the most profitable treasures. You don't wanna buy from a wholesale seller or such - after all, that means less profit. You'll give them some equipment, maybe some food, and then hope they come back alive. Perhaps they will. After all, you play them. But if they die, you can only take a few things with you back up. Maybe you'll sell something to them, later, when they come browsing. At just under 150% of it's base price.Underneath that cute exterior is a game about making money.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												I'd say the 82% Metascore is pretty spot on. A lot of fun, and sometimes you can just pick it up and sink a couple hours into it without feeling overly committed. Not the absolute best game of all time, but certainly has its charm.I'd recommend it to anyone who enjoys light simulation-RPGs in the style of Rune Factory; the dungeons are pretty simplistic but still good cheap fun. I'm also impressed with the localization job; a lot of the Japanese dialogue is almost spot on for the first line of text.Suggestions to draw out the enjoyment factor are:- Go to a dungeon at least twice per game week, and clear out a 5 level stretch. Only playing the shop aspect can get really repetitive without a break, and you're really going to be missing out on a lot of gameplay aspects if you don't do both.- Don't read too many FAQs and guides unless you're stuck; the programming isn't the most sophisticated and it's really easy to find the tricks and exploits that make the game a cakewalk. Try to find the tricks yourself, it's a major part of the fun.- Plug in a PS3/XBOX/PC USB game controller if you have one, it'll make the dungeons more relaxing and fun instead of annoying- Once you get a good idea of how the game works, try to beat the game in a single "loop". (Your save games will indicate how many times you continued after a game over or started a new game plus over a previous game.)Have fun, and don't let Euria into your shop!

content:
Posted: December 25, 2010
												A friend asked me, "HOW IS THIS GAME SO FUN?" I replied, "It is kind of impressive how fun it is being an NPC, isn't it?" And it is. You can't really summarize this game; it's got too many great things going for it, and attempts to do so generally result in disbelief that a game like that can be as entertaining as claimed.The game's about running an item shop. Initially you have to pay off your debt but once that's done you enter "Endless Mode" and can enjoy being a merchant (and also running through dungeons to get loot!) to your heart's content. Don't be disheartened by failure; even if you fail to pay off your debt, you'll still get a second chance.Good luck getting 100% completion; the post-endgame content is ridiculously beefy, and filling out your item encyclopedia requires at least six or seven playthroughs. And even when you've got that sorted out, you STILL have Endless Mode to challenge yourself with.Also it's an indie title, if you like that sort of thing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2013
												Recettear is fun, charming, and an original take on the JRPG genre. It combines simulation elements with the RPG genre. In the game, you run an item shop in an attempt to pay off Recette's father's debt with the help of the fairy Tear, who also works for the company collecting the debt. In the game you will meet many adventurers, whom you can hire to go with you into dungeons to look for loot to sell in your shop. Micro-management is a big factor in this game, as you need to make sure to have enough money at the end of the week to pay off your debt. Each day is set into four segments, and each time you open the store or leave the shop costs a segment, while going into a dungeon will cost three. If you don't have enough money when your debt is due, then you will need to start at the beginning but with character progress getting carried over. Overall, this is a great game that JRPG fans should definitely not pass up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												The game is fun and offers some stratagy based money management as well as requiring a bit of luck.In standard new game there are only 2 dungeons, one is basically a tutorial dungeon with not a lot to offer the other is a 3 part dungeon with a 4th area allowing you to fight just the bosses over and over again.Early in the game dungeon crawling is a must to gain pix, however later on, for me it was after just the 2nd week, it no longer seems really helpful.Often times townspeople will come in selling an item and then before the time segment is even over will buy it right back. One of the best ways to make money is buying for 30% and reselling for 130%.One of the best items to stock up I found was weapons, in later weeks they get boosts in value and can be sold for as much as 300% base. For me the last 3 days all weapons were increased in value, not sure if it was luck or game mechanics, but in the last 3 days alone I amassed over 300k pix.The game does have NG+ as well as a survival mode, but for the most part there doesn't really seem to be a whole lot of replay value after you intitally beat it.I bought it on sale for 9.99, not 100% I got my moneys worth, but it was definitely a fun game. I have a total of around 7 hours in the game including offline time, and that's about the amount of time it took me to beat it with having to start over once. I'd recommend buying it, but definitely on sale for 9.99 or less simply because of how short the game is, and how little replay value it offers in my opinion.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												How can I recommend this game enough... it is so incredibly good.  It is cute, it is engaging, it has a great story and is localized to a T every time; running the store is fun, adventuring on each character is fun, and the personal challenge mode availability is fun.  (i.e. just for fun, play through and make yourself finish every dungeon on your first run-through without stopping or failing, although you will experience loot anguish.)  The alternate modes that are available are also fun to begin with.This is - alternately run an item shop and go adventuring, and as a result, do various collecting of all the story, all the things, all the money, all the characters, and various vanquishing of all the monsters, traps, and dungeons.Take the above, add the Cute descriptor, add the Fun descriptor, and add a whole bunch of interesting internal mechanics and you get my lots of hours.Anyway, this is one of my favorite games, so this has been my feeble attempt at a review.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												It's such a casual, yet deep dungeon runner with loveable characters and easy-to-play controls. Although it is lacking in story materials, the main fun just comes from the running of your own item store. Every hirable adventurer has their own unique playstyle ranging from warrior, thief, archer, lancer, mage. The adventurers also have their quirks and characteristics that make you want to play as them. If you can't pay your debt in time, you start again from day one, but your adventurers still have their items and stats (but you have to find them again,) and the stores retain the items that they sold you from your previous progression through the game.Some bosses and enemies come back from Chantelise, but it's not really a bad thing as the game is not very hard until you get to the later dungeons (then it gets pretty hardcore.)One of the most enjoyable RPG's i have ever played

Posted: August 6, 2011
												A fun game where you run an item shop and can also explore dungeons, by hiring adventurers, looking for items. You play as Recette who has to make money to pay off her father's debt in a few weekly payments with the cost going up as time winds on. She is accompanied by Tear, a fairy hired by the finance company to collect on the debt. The interplay between the two is usually amusing and entertaining.It's a type of game you don't see very often and is surprisingly well done. The script is well written and often funny. It's a cute and quirky game. Capitalism, ho!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												I'm not a big fan of anime or the clichés tied to it, but Recettear does, on the surface, rather look like a game made to appease the clique of rabid otaku. This served as a deterrant for me, but it's only skin-deep: the try-hard cutesy voice acting is minimal and can be disabled, the story doesn't involve an overly emotional hero with amnesia, and there is no harem of scantily-clad children. That's the usual suspects taken care of.Recettear places you in the shoes of a girl named Recette, in a fairly typical JRPG setting. It turns out that Recette's father — who is now probably dead, which is beautifully glossed over — accrued a significant debt, and she's to pay it off by turning her home into an item shop. Your primary goal is making money rather than story or dungeon progression, which is quite a twist from the norm. The story doesn't try to do too much, and gets out of your way pretty quickly.Items can be acquired at the local wholesalers or in dungeons. Yep, dungeons: you can hire an adventurer, kit them out with your own gear, and take them dungeon crawling. They even have their own levelling system and skills, though the combat system is fairly basic and uninteresting. Then there's crafting, in which you discover new items by combining others.But you own an item shop, so you should be selling items. This process involves judging your customers' budgets, haggling, buying from customers, keeping up with item trends, taking pre-orders and appropriately stocking your shop. Speaking of the shop, it's customisable through a range of carpets, counters and wallpaper. Your shop can even be expanded and the furniture can be moved around.There's quite a lot to Recettear, but you're not thrown in at the deep end: everything is revealed at what I can only call a perfect pace. Just as I was getting used to one mechanic, a new one popped up. Once the main game is completed — that is, once you've paid back the debt —  New Game+, Survival and Endless modes are unlocked, with plenty more items left to discover and levels to gain. To gauge just how much content there is here, I completed the main game with only 33% of items discovered and a merchant level of 19 (of 50).All in all, I thoroughly enjoyed this game and will probably be playing a little Endless mode, in which there is no looming debt to repay, for some time.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2010
												Different is the name of the game with this quirky little RPG/Economy game, Recttear.  Somewhat difficult to explain, Recttear must be experienced to be fully understood. You own a store and hire characters to go down into the dungeon to fetch you treasure to sell. The game is split into those two basic parts; selling the goods at the store, and hunting in the darkened dungeon to find lost treasures. This two part approach worked for me as I found myself playing to get my store awesome and my heroes to be ultra-awesome. Recttear is a bit dated and the story is basically devoid, but the game is very fun and highly addictive. You’ll find yourself mumbling just one more level often as you tack on the hours in this enjoyable game.

												When I purchased this game, I was expecting just another generic FPS. However, when I threw it into my 360 I was instead greeted by one of the most innovative experiences in the genre to date. The single player campaign mode is in itself gripping and emotional. I really felt attached to all of the characters and the soundtrack is positively moving. The gameplay is unique, but at the same time familiar and smooth. The multiplayer missions are also a wonderful gaming experience: challenging you to work well with your teammates as well as strategically attack and defend for yourself. Overall, it's obvious that Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale is the best Call of Duty experience (and perhaps the best FPS experience) in gaming history.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												Have you ever felt the urge to try your hand as a rpg item shop owner? No? Me either until I played this game. Recettear is an awesome little indy game with a unique feel and a surprising level of depth. The game revolves around a cheerful young girl named Recette who after having her father squander the family fortune to fund a dungeon adventure she is left with only one option. She has to turn her house into an item shop and get her fathers debt under control! I highly recommend this game. It has a unique sense of humor features original and fun game play.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												Simple game of buy low / sell high, with a little dungeon crawling for entertainment. I enjoyed it, but low replayability once you clear it.'New game +' has exactly the same difficulty level as the original (same debt and deadline), so it's actually easier to clear. What it gives you is your expensive items unlocked so you can easily earn the total debt in 1 week. What to do with the extra time? Go wander around town looking for events, more characters and dungeons.Achievement chasers who want to complete the item encyclopedia may appreciate this, not so much for those looking for a challenge.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												Got this game on sale for $4.99. Worth it? Completly.This game is an anime game, which typically pushes most of the "gamer" catagory away, but do not run. This game is fantastic. I was a bit uneasy purchasing an anime game, as I am not a big fan of cute anime stuff, but i'm glad I went for it. You take on the role of a girl (Recette of Recettear) and your goal is to payback a loan that your adventurer father left after he dissapeared. The character that runs with you the whole game is a fairy, yes, fairy named "Tear". The two combined makes the name of the game/shop. Tear gets you started and teaches you how to run a shop in the game, and you buy items, sell items, and complete orders at your store to make money. You can also take command of many different warriors to take on dungeons head on. Dungeons will allow you to score some low-priced, loot that you can sell in your store, completly for free. Market prices vary in the game depending on fictional situations. I.E. Candy shortage in the town over, makes the price of candy double for a short time. They can also go down with the situations. Having these price variations makes you keep lots of stock of certain items, buy when they're low, sell when they're high, etc. Instead of just buying an item and selling it, you always want lots of variations.Another aspect of the game, which I personally find excellent is that your warriors will come into your store, and purchase goods. When they do so, the goods they purchase will be equipped on them for their next battles. It's always good to hold off on selling certain items to the townspeople and waiting for your warrior to come in to buy it.After you pay off your final loan, you see some anime cutscene of "I love you, Don't leave fairy loanshark girl" and you can continue on playing until you pull your hair out from hearing "do you have _____" Which you just sold out of.All in all, This game honestly, is one of my top 10 games on steam. The fact a $4.99 tiny indie game can hold such honor over many $59.99 AAA titles, is a huge award. Buy this, even at full price. If you love RPG's, and ever wanted to own a shop in one,(Like me in Oblivion/Skyrim) it's a must.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												This game is more than just get, sell, buy, sell... It's more of an RPG.The trading part of the game is just the ultimate goal of the adventure.You see, to trade things and earn money, you need to befriend adventurers, so you'll have to activate events and then level them up. Once you've befriended an adventurer you get his/her card, once you have their card, you can start the loop over, and still have them available!Then it get's a bit complicated; the more you level them up, the more they will cost. Except the adventurer you start out with, he'll cost you either a set amount, which gets higher the more you level him up, or however much money you have on you. So you'll have to step up the game to be able to get to more area's if you want to actually earn anything.Add to that a coming disaster, when an evil magician starts to stir up some trouble, meanwhile, you're still in large debt. You'll have to defeat this evil magician and pay off your debt, if not, you'll have to start over.But starting over isn't such a bad thing, you'll be doing it lots. If you lose, don't worry! It was all just a bad dream... Although all the stuff you got in that dream is still in your inventory. Except all that sweet, sweet money.This game is also very much a visual novel, that means lots of reading. I like that, and if you like it, I recommend you check out "Steins;Gate", which you can buy on JList! But don't worry, it has a skip function, in case you don't like reading. What kind of visual novel is it? Slice of life and comedy.Recettear is one of my favorite games on Steam, highly recommended.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												edit: gonna re-write this after i play it againNow this is a pretty neat game. I, unfortunately, never got too into it but I did like how it was done.The story is okay and works for the game. You play a young girl that runs a shop and you go around collecting things to sell in it. You get to decorate the shop too.There's a little town to explore with some different stores and there's also dungeons to venture into with bosses and whatnot. So the game does have combat and a handful of different characters to use when doing it. The visuals were pretty good - though I don't like the 2d sprites used in the 3d environment. A lot of games like this do that and I've never liked it. The music worked well with the game.It was pretty fun bargaining with people and selling items I collected. The dungeons were basic, but fun enough to go through as well.If you think the game sounds fun then pick it up and you'll probably like it.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
												Fun, fun, and fun.This has a nice little small business Sim attached to it is a old school dungeon crawler system. I enjoyed everythinggameplay 9/10mix between a sim of running your shop and a dungeon crawlersoundtrack 7/10sound effects can become irritating over time, but not immediently so. But both the music and sound effects are enjoyable and fit well to the game.Story 8/10 Without too high expectations this is very enjoyable. A girl is left to fend for herself after a fairy shows up saying your missing deadbeat dad has left all his debt to you. Not epic cut scenes or anything, but visual novel and cute dungeon craw animation.Controls */*I prefer the use of a controller for the dungeon part of the game, but works fine with keyboard and mouse. It's well done for either way, but i think just comes down to personal preference.This game is truely one of my favorite purchases on steam.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
Recommendation:If you're not that much into story or not at all into JRPGs, this is probably not for you, but otherwise, it feels so different, original and funny, that i can definetly recommend it.About the game:This game is awesomely weird and weirdly awesome. The sounds are nothing special (after some time i turned them down and let my music play in the background) and visuals may have been average at the time of its making (2007) and are now definetly outdated, but they're nice and serve the atmosphere of the game well enough. But that atmosphere is just funny in so many ways - i love it!It's also pretty neat, that you can play the game in multiple ways - you can just use the trade mechanics to go through most of the game, or you can spend a lot of time in dungeons if you want to. Though mixing it up is probably best for both the player and the game. And if you're a completionist you need both parts and a good amount of time, as after one regular playthrough and over 20 hours of playtime, i'm not even at 50%. It's also your choice how much you want to follow the background stories, though i'd say that they make up a lot of the charme of it all. Sometimes it feels like there are some very unpolished edges, but then again, often that just seems to fit into the game's quirkyness.About the experience:"Dear diary,a few months ago dad left to get cig... eh, to become a hero and he hasn't come back ever since. So, until a few weeks ago, i was living on my own, i managed to get by, but it was a bit lonely. So, i was surprised, when some day a fairy named Tear knocked at the door and told me about dad's debts and some contract, that i would have to pay them and that i could do that by opening and manageing an item shop. I didn't quite get it, but i was happy that Tear said that she'd help me and that i had something to do now.Since then i've learned a lot about running a shop. We even met a broke adventurer who couldn't afford the entrance exam for the adventurer's guild, so we started to sponsor him in exchange for the loot found in the dungeons. I've also met a lot of other people and apparently even got a rival now.Sometimes things can get hard, when the economy just isn't working in my favor, or people aren't satisfied with my shopkeeping, or monsters seem to act erratic and beat up adventurers in the dungeons. And when i have troubles getting the money for the debt payments, i get nightmares about being evicted. But i guess that's just how live works, sometimes it's random, like a couple of fish flying in your face. So i just stick to my motto, "capitalism ho" and move on.But usually life is good around here. People make a lot of funny jokes and references and even though i'm not sure if i get all of them, it's always something to laugh about. Plus, language seems to be weird sometimes - for example, i'm pretty sure that Tear is actually saying "♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; in french a lot.So, i'll contintue to become the best merchant and most successfull sponsor around.- 'Recette Lemongrass', now proud owner of the item shop 'Recettear'."

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												This game is... strange, in a good way.It's all about running an item shop and crawling through dungeons for items to sell, or ingrediants to make better items. The start is a bit slow and the combat could be better, but it picks up quickly as the days go by. The story of the game is all about you being the daughter of an infamous adventurer who left a massive debt in his name, and you're the only one who can clear it. With the help of the business fairy, Tear, you'll work through a month to pay off the debt... or you'll have to sell your house!Good things about this game:+Good music+Unique theme+Various items to find and a unique system for equipping your adventurer with items+Various characters to run through the dungeon with+Dialog is interesting, if not a little childish due to the age of the main character+Beating the game, or failing to do so, will allow you to 'restart' with all your items and 'Merchent Level' in tact. This lets you get up in money much faster than you would do so at the start, but you don't keep any of your money or your progress through events.+Decent end-game content that makes it worth while to try and get what you need+Haggling is a pretty neat concept, though it takes practice to get it down right.+Characters are interesting and have their own unique style, in dungeons and just in general. Bad things about this game:-Combat could definitely be better, with hit-scan and certain abilities. Some characters are just notably better than others.-Events are picky. You have to know when you need to go to places in town to get certain chat boxes, which can affect how you get items, characters, or unlock a new location. This causes you to lose a 'block' of time, too, and not all events do anything.-One girl will come in and sell you something and refuse to buy anything. She'll always refuse to sell at 100% of the item's price, too. 200% is the minimum for her, and there's no way to get rid of her after she appears. You can refuse to buy it, but this messes up your combo and makes you level up slower. -Getting the 'true card' for characters takes too long. True cards let you use your adventurer without having to find them in the story, which can be helpful for clearing dungeons again. But getting the True Card requires you to beat the game and use that adventurer the most. (More than any other adventurer, that is, for that month.)  To get another one, you have to play the game /again/ and use a different adventurer. -There's little 'stats' to the game that you can see, at least in my experience. There /are/ stats, but you can't really see them except when your adventurer is buying an item that is better than what they have. You can't even see how much people like you to adjust your prices.Despite the lengthy part of the 'bad stuff', I really just offered more explanation as to what and why it was bad. This game is still amazing to play, especially if you like dungeon crawlers. The 'bad' things are just my opinion, anyways, and the good things weren't as descriptive because I don't want to spoil anything!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												Truly a sleeper hit.  When I purchased this game I was expecting a fairly cutesy shop simulator and not much beyond that and boy howdy although I was right on that there is so much more to this.  The big part of this game that steals the show comes from the dialogue and the great translation.  It feels similar to Earthbound in that there's some quirk to it that just makes you grin, although I'd argue this does it better.  Despite having the shiny atmosphere the game is also quite challenging with the debts you must pay for the Item Shop and you will have to push yourself to ensure your income makes it in time.  In addition to managing items, selling high, and buying low you also have a side story that comes in the form of dungeon crawling which is again something I did not expect.  The dungeon crawling I'd argue is just average truth be told, cause while it does have the standard looting, random drops, and boss battles the later dungeons get enourmous and it makes navigation a royal pain since the floors are randomized and you can have as many as thirty rooms on a single floor.  TL;DRA surprisingly engaging game with a great script, average dungeon crawling, and a good level of challenge.  Pick it up when you get the chance!

I, unfortunately, never got too into it but I did like how it was done.The story is okay and works for the game. You play a young girl that runs a shop and you go around collecting things to sell in it. You get to decorate the shop too.There's a little town to explore with some different stores and there's also dungeons to venture into with bosses and whatnot. So the game does have combat and a handful of different characters to use when doing it. The visuals were pretty good - though I don't like the 2d sprites used in the 3d environment. A lot of games like this do that and I've never liked it. The music worked well with the game.It was pretty fun bargaining with people and selling items I collected. The dungeons were basic, but fun enough to go through as well.If you think the game sounds fun then pick it up and you'll probably like it.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
Recommendation:If you're not that much into story or not at all into JRPGs, this is probably not for you, but otherwise, it feels so different, original and funny, that i can definetly recommend it.About the game:This game is awesomely weird and weirdly awesome. The sounds are nothing special (after some time i turned them down and let my music play in the background) and visuals may have been average at the time of its making (2007) and are now definetly outdated, but they're nice and serve the atmosphere of the game well enough. But that atmosphere is just funny in so many ways - i love it!It's also pretty neat, that you can play the game in multiple ways - you can just use the trade mechanics to go through most of the game, or you can spend a lot of time in dungeons if you want to. Though mixing it up is probably best for both the player and the game. And if you're a completionist you need both parts and a good amount of time, as after one regular playthrough and over 20 hours of playtime, i'm not even at 50%. It's also your choice how much you want to follow the background stories, though i'd say that they make up a lot of the charme of it all. Sometimes it feels like there are some very unpolished edges, but then again, often that just seems to fit into the game's quirkyness.About the experience:"Dear diary,a few months ago dad left to get cig... eh, to become a hero and he hasn't come back ever since. So, until a few weeks ago, i was living on my own, i managed to get by, but it was a bit lonely. So, i was surprised, when some day a fairy named Tear knocked at the door and told me about dad's debts and some contract, that i would have to pay them and that i could do that by opening and manageing an item shop. I didn't quite get it, but i was happy that Tear said that she'd help me and that i had something to do now.Since then i've learned a lot about running a shop. We even met a broke adventurer who couldn't afford the entrance exam for the adventurer's guild, so we started to sponsor him in exchange for the loot found in the dungeons. I've also met a lot of other people and apparently even got a rival now.Sometimes things can get hard, when the economy just isn't working in my favor, or people aren't satisfied with my shopkeeping, or monsters seem to act erratic and beat up adventurers in the dungeons. And when i have troubles getting the money for the debt payments, i get nightmares about being evicted. But i guess that's just how live works, sometimes it's random, like a couple of fish flying in your face. So i just stick to my motto, "capitalism ho" and move on.But usually life is good around here. People make a lot of funny jokes and references and even though i'm not sure if i get all of them, it's always something to laugh about. Plus, language seems to be weird sometimes - for example, i'm pretty sure that Tear is actually saying "♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; in french a lot.So, i'll contintue to become the best merchant and most successfull sponsor around.- 'Recette Lemongrass', now proud owner of the item shop 'Recettear'."
