content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
												Your father has left you all alone and you inherited his shop. You're twelve with no business experience but still this is generally awesome. WAIT there's more! You also recieved an unmentionable ammount of debt! You have a friend who is a fairy, this place is racist against fairies, just saying no equal opportunities so they work through a company that helps them find work as bill collectors who will repossess your house and the shop your father left you. rude.You start out buying from other places and selling it in your shop at rediculously jacked up prices. The little girl wont buy anything ever, I hate her face she calls me dumb when I want a measly 5% mark up on an Item. I'm a twelve year old in debt here!It's ok I'm pretty sure the old man is a pedophile, he buys my stuff at a 40% mark up if not then I drop it to 35% and he praises how good a deal it is. I mean seriously when's the last time you paid 550pix for a crappy wood bow someone probably made in 5 minutes? Also he only buys weapons I think he's a part of a secret plot to overthrow our goverment. Damn commies.You're kind of an airhead and have terrible low self esteem, I am pretty sure you contiplate suicide everytime someone doesn't buy your goods...overpriced goods.No one likes Beef Bowls....You find friends who you take into dungeons to kill things, this is lucritive for business but you're kind of rude hidding in a super safe bubble while they die for you. Then you sell them gear but they are greedy and want discounts so I am ok with letting them use crappy gear.Some chick keeps sending her husband to buy armor. I'm not sure what they are into but i'm pretty sure I want that DVD. All in all this game is awesome, I like it. You should too. I'm sure it'll be on sale during summer so don't spend twenty dollars. That's just smart planning.Also you're pretty and people like you for who you are, except me I don't know you, but I'm sure my statement is correct.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
												Fun, fun, and fun.This has a nice little small business Sim attached to it is a old school dungeon crawler system. I enjoyed everythinggameplay 9/10mix between a sim of running your shop and a dungeon crawlersoundtrack 7/10sound effects can become irritating over time, but not immediently so. But both the music and sound effects are enjoyable and fit well to the game.Story 8/10 Without too high expectations this is very enjoyable. A girl is left to fend for herself after a fairy shows up saying your missing deadbeat dad has left all his debt to you. The story progresses as you pay off this debt and find new heros to fight for you as you enter dungeons looking for sweet loot.Animation 9/10I honestly don't know what else I could want animation wise. It's all cute. Not epic cut scenes or anything, but visual novel and cute dungeon craw animation.Controls */*I prefer the use of a controller for the dungeon part of the game, but works fine with keyboard and mouse. It's well done for either way, but i think just comes down to personal preference.This game is truely one of my favorite purchases on steam.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												Got this game on sale for $4.99. Worth it? Completly.This game is an anime game, which typically pushes most of the "gamer" catagory away, but do not run. This game is fantastic. I was a bit uneasy purchasing an anime game, as I am not a big fan of cute anime stuff, but i'm glad I went for it. You take on the role of a girl (Recette of Recettear) and your goal is to payback a loan that your adventurer father left after he dissapeared. The character that runs with you the whole game is a fairy, yes, fairy named "Tear". The two combined makes the name of the game/shop. Tear gets you started and teaches you how to run a shop in the game, and you buy items, sell items, and complete orders at your store to make money. You can also take command of many different warriors to take on dungeons head on. Dungeons will allow you to score some low-priced, loot that you can sell in your store, completly for free. Market prices vary in the game depending on fictional situations. I.E. Candy shortage in the town over, makes the price of candy double for a short time. They can also go down with the situations. Having these price variations makes you keep lots of stock of certain items, buy when they're low, sell when they're high, etc. Instead of just buying an item and selling it, you always want lots of variations.Another aspect of the game, which I personally find excellent is that your warriors will come into your store, and purchase goods. When they do so, the goods they purchase will be equipped on them for their next battles. It's always good to hold off on selling certain items to the townspeople and waiting for your warrior to come in to buy it.After you pay off your final loan, you see some anime cutscene of "I love you, Don't leave fairy loanshark girl" and you can continue on playing until you pull your hair out from hearing "do you have _____" Which you just sold out of.All in all, This game honestly, is one of my top 10 games on steam. The fact a $4.99 tiny indie game can hold such honor over many $59.99 AAA titles, is a huge award. Buy this, even at full price. If you love RPG's, and ever wanted to own a shop in one,(Like me in Oblivion/Skyrim) it's a must.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
STORY & GAMEPLAYDue to her father's debt, Recette open an item store to pay the debt. A large amount of debt -_-. She runs the store with help/guidance from her fairy debt-collector 'companion', Tear. Every some period of time (about weekly) Recette must pay certain amount of money (called 'pix' in this game) to Tear. If she unable to pay, Tear will take her house as payment for the debt. Funny story, a fairy debt-collector 'companion' assist errr, more precisely, force a little girl to pay her father's debt..... ._.Although the story sounds funny, the gameplay is a little bit... hard. If you unable to collect certain amount of pix at the payment date (which getting bigger & bigger amount of pix at the next week), you'll lose your house and live in a cardbox. But..., don't worry about that... ;)Well, even with that cruel debt, the game itself is interesting to play. There are three ways to get item stock to sell on your store:1. Buy items from market & guild2. Explore dungeons to get some items there3. Fusion (combine various items to get new items)To explore dungeons, you can't go there alone. You must hire an adventurer. As more days passed & events happen, more adventurers will be unlocked. You can equip the adventurer with items you have in your inventory. If you succeed defeating monsters & bosses on the dungeons, you can bring all items you've collected. But if you failed, you can bring only few items. The dungeon is randomized so it'll never be the same when you go there again. Nice feature.You can do fusion at the guild. The variety & rank of items you can fusion is depend on your merchant level. The higher your level the more items, of course. The merchant level also affects what kind of items you can find on market & guild, and items dropped from the monsters on dungeons. Also, how much you can decorate your item store is depend on it too. It's also affect your haggle/bargain skill when you open your store and start selling items to your customers :)Capitalism, ho!GRAPHICSWell, obviously, Japanese style anime characters. I won't say much about graphics. It's good enough. Good variety of background, so much variety of items, colorful. Nice graphics.MUSICThe soundtracks is good enough. The character voice is in Japanese. But don't worry, all the text is in English :)Suggestion: If you found some problem with (menu) scrolling, see the solution here.Story: 8/10Gameplay: 8/10Graphics: 8/10Music: 7.5/10Overall score: 7.8/10

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												This was one of the first games I bought on Steam, and I stand by my decision to buy it after all these years. It is a game that puts an unique spin on the RPG item shop staple, by forcing you to take a crash course in profit-making, stock management, and haggling. Hell, calling this Baby's First Management wouldn't be far off if the game wasn't so unforgivable on those that don't cater to their clients (Then again, it's not like starting from the beginning was a brutal punishment when you keep your things, but still).Fans of dungeon crawling, on the other hand, won't be dissapointed as the adventuring feels very well done, and, more importantly, each of your mercenary pals not only plays differently, they really feel differently, right down to movement and battle mechanics. This might not seem strange in a game tailored around the theme, but in a game focused on store management this comes as a pleasant surprise.Also, the ammount of content in this game is absurd: The story itself isn't exactly long, and as you struggle against the loan deadlines you may come to loathe the moment when no other shoppers try to buy something it may feel short, but trying to get all the true adventurer cards, trying to fill out your in-game glossary, and really, just trying to get the true end itself will feel like you're playing one of those JRPGs that have no end in sight after a hundred hours.If the economics, the dungeon crawling and the collecting still haven't sold you into it, maybe you'll give it a shot for the sheer hillarity and referencing in this game. And remember, the demo is there to help you make a more informed decision than what the shopkeeper tells you, so give it a shot before buying. Finally, it's not like you can't haggle the price down, if you decide to buy it eventually, after all, that's what steam sales are for. Capitalism, ho!

content:
Posted: September 26, 2012
												Very fun!I feel this needs to be elaborated more, as I have finally cleared the main game and off to the post-game content. It took me a very long while to finish this as I had failed the last payment on my first time, and after finding out it sets you back on day 2, I got demotivated (that's not entirely true though, apparently you keep your end-game items when you reset so you get that extra boost on your next try, but I did not know that back then), but after giving it another go I was able to finish it with money to spare.This game... Is AMAZING... this is something that costs like 10 bucks, I bought for something like 3 and I've already accumulated 44 hours and I intend to play even more for the post-game. The graphics are cute, the voice acting is great though it is not fully voiced, the dungeons are simple but interesting, though it is my complaint that they are too lengthy, depending on the character you choose it will take about 2 hours or something to clear unless you are rushing it (but then you miss out on phat lewt, who would want to miss out on phat lewt?). I guess if there was an end-game tier item that automatically revealed the map when you took it could cut out on some of that time as you'd only move to the treasure chests? I did not check if there actually is an item like that, though.I'd say the dungeons make up about 3/4 of the time you'd spend on the game (mainly due to how lengthy they are), and for the last fourth you'll be selling stuff in the shop, though it may be a bit awkward at start, you eventually get used to it. There are many numbers and percentages involved that you can only find out through experimentation or visiting the wiki, I'd say it's worth skimming over them or else you'll screw yourself over on your first run. Also, I'd say thank god that the text for when you buy or sell has a different color, because the speech before it sometimes sound a bit ambiguous.I really hope I can find other gems like this one in the future. Thank you based Comiket, thank you based EGS, and thank you based Carpe Fulgur!Capitalism, ho!

												So let me get this straight.I am a little girl. My father is an adventurer with massive debt, who is probably dead. The banks, who my father owes a lot of money to, have come to collect from me. They know I don't have any money, but they allow me to open a shop to pay them with the stores revenue. But:-Despite that fact that my father might have died adventuring, I send adventurers to collect money for me from dungeons.-If I miss one payment to the bank they foreclose upon my store and throw me onto the streets, knowing I would never be able to pay them back.-I am a fan of capitalism, despite being one bounced check away from dying in the streets.9/10 would storyline again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
STORY & GAMEPLAYDue to her father's debt, Recette open an item store to pay the debt. A large amount of debt -_-. She runs the store with help/guidance from her fairy debt-collector 'companion', Tear. Every some period of time (about weekly) Recette must pay certain amount of money (called 'pix' in this game) to Tear. If she unable to pay, Tear will take her house as payment for the debt. Funny story, a fairy debt-collector 'companion' assist errr, more precisely, force a little girl to pay her father's debt..... ._.Although the story sounds funny, the gameplay is a little bit... hard. If you unable to collect certain amount of pix at the payment date (which getting bigger & bigger amount of pix at the next week), you'll lose your house and live in a cardbox. But..., don't worry about that... ;)Well, even with that cruel debt, the game itself is interesting to play. There are three ways to get item stock to sell on your store:1. Buy items from market & guild2. Explore dungeons to get some items there3. Fusion (combine various items to get new items)To explore dungeons, you can't go there alone. You must hire an adventurer. As more days passed & events happen, more adventurers will be unlocked. You can equip the adventurer with items you have in your inventory. If you succeed defeating monsters & bosses on the dungeons, you can bring all items you've collected. But if you failed, you can bring only few items. The dungeon is randomized so it'll never be the same when you go there again. Nice feature.You can do fusion at the guild. The variety & rank of items you can fusion is depend on your merchant level. The higher your level the more items, of course. The merchant level also affects what kind of items you can find on market & guild, and items dropped from the monsters on dungeons. Also, how much you can decorate your item store is depend on it too. It's also affect your haggle/bargain skill when you open your store and start selling items to your customers :)Capitalism, ho!GRAPHICSWell, obviously, Japanese style anime characters. I won't say much about graphics. It's good enough. Good variety of background, so much variety of items, colorful. Nice graphics.MUSICThe soundtracks is good enough. The character voice is in Japanese. But don't worry, all the text is in English :)Suggestion: If you found some problem with (menu) scrolling, see the solution here.Story: 8/10Gameplay: 8/10Graphics: 8/10Music: 7.5/10Overall score: 7.8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												Summary: Great game with a few rough patches... Well worth the purchase.Good: This game's combat, while pretty easy to wrap your head around, is surprisingly gratifying as your heroes level up. The abilities feel really fun, and dungeon exploring does a good job of being tense and challenging throughout the game. Combining a store style sim with an action combat mechanic is by no means a new idea, but it's executed very well here. The store management system is fun and very in depth. I had a great time tweaking my store's aesthetics and placement, choosing where each item goes based on how that will affect my sales. If you like store management games, action rpgs, or both, you're going to find something to love here.Bad: In all honesty, I was unimpressed by the game's story. While some of the characters were interesting, the main plot and a lot of the side plots were kind of dull, and I found myself wading through text trying to get to the next part of the game. A good story draws you in, not forces you to skip it. Also, you have regular bills to pay each week, and the last one is suddenly, terrifyingly large. Ugly: I only have one complaint large enough to be called "Ugly": To craft the really good items to sell in your store, you need material items, some of which are seemingly impossible to find. Any game that requires me to hunt down a wiki to complete is probably doing something wrong. Complaints aside, this game was impressively fun and engaging. Definitely check it out.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale is a cute anime themed game about a young girl who starts an item shop business in a small village. That's the official story. What Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale is actually about is a young girl abandoned by her father at a young age who is quickly conned by a 'well wishing fairy' who loans her an extraordinary amount of money to allow her to start a tiny business and extorts her with exorbiant amounts of interest. Taking this deal with the devil, she begins earnestly to start this tiny business. She begins bright eyed and innocent, only selling items at a fair price and buying items from others for a fair price. However, due to the huge repayments that she is required to pay back, she eventually is driven to profiteering over other people's suffering by charging exorbiant amounts of pix (gold) for simple items during times of famine or desperation. In her greed she starts to hire young adventurers to raid dangerous dungeons and taking everything they find. Often putting their lives in dire danger over a few trinkets. By the end of the game she has turned from what was a young girl trying to keep her small business afloat to a fraudulent conwoman, taking advantage of the unfortunate townfolk who happened to wander in and revelling in their misfortune. Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale is an artistic masterwork detailing the temptations of financial immorality. Truly a wonderful game.

												As someone who vaguely enjoys a good japanese-style rpg every now and then, I can safely say that Recettear: AIST is a stunningly well done game. The music is semi-retro SNES / early PS1 (in the best way possible i mean), the dungenons are fun and satisfying, and overall the game has a great personality. The japanese-only sfx dialog is a little irritating at times but it can be forgiven, especially with the great presentation and fun factor. TL;DR Highly recommended, very unique RPG that puts a nice twist on a basic dungeon crawler.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												Okay. If you're curious to find out what kind of game this is, It is a game about capitalism, and running your own little items shop as the title of the game implies. It has a decent combat system, a likeable protagonist, and very nice guidelines to learn how to play most effectively. Although the music does get VERY aggravating at times in my opinion. All in all, I have had an absolute blast with this game. Pros: 1. Good shop customization         2. Decent characters and storyline         3. Rewarding combat system, addicting gameplay that keeps you occupied for hours.Cons: 1. Wonky movement with the arrow keys when you're fighting in a dungeon. (It's tolerable)          2. Repetitive music and voices. (I had to turn those off within the first hour of gameplay)          3. THE BLONDE ♥♥♥♥♥ AND HER FAIRY THAT TRIES TO BUY♥♥♥♥♥♥FOR 3% OVER THE BASE PRICE, AND KIDS WHO COME INTO YOUR SHOP WITH THEIR LUNCH MONEY AND PICK OUT A 7,000 PIX SWORD AND WON'T PAY UP!Other than that. Great game. I rate 9/10 :)

content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												Recettear is a game you should get if you are looking for a nice break from the major titles currently drowning the market on all platforms from the handheld to the consoles. Its cute, sincere, well put together and designed in a way where all the mechanics work together to create a stronger experience. Its not a stand out in anything, but it does all of the right things well enough to make it stand head and shoulders above many other games. I wouldn't go so far as to call it a modern classic, but its definitely a good game that I do recommend that people play. CAPITALISM, HO!If you want to read a detailed review about the game feel free to have a look at it on my blog: http://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2014/08/recettear-item-shops-tale.html.

Posted: September 10, 2014
												The tutorials are hand-holding, the challenge level is punishing, and some of the characters are a little annoying (if adorable), but /Recettear/ is absolutely worth a shot, especially if you don't think you'll like it. The game looks like a JRPG, but it doesn't have the hand-holding character of FF13, or even of FF6; it's more like a roguelike with a graphics budget than it is like anything else. (Be warned, you can't win the game with shopkeeping alone. Nor with dungeon crawling alone -- I think you need to go for item creation as soon as the game starts hinting that it might be a good idea...)

content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												Recettear is a game you should get if you are looking for a nice break from the major titles currently drowning the market on all platforms from the handheld to the consoles. Its cute, sincere, well put together and designed in a way where all the mechanics work together to create a stronger experience. Its not a stand out in anything, but it does all of the right things well enough to make it stand head and shoulders above many other games. I wouldn't go so far as to call it a modern classic, but its definitely a good game that I do recommend that people play. CAPITALISM, HO!If you want to read a detailed review about the game feel free to have a look at it on my blog: http://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2014/08/recettear-item-shops-tale.html.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2013
												At first glance, Recettear may seem like some generic Japanese game, and the reason for this is that it doesn't do much to present itself as anything else; however, the game is one of the more unique titles I've seen among the massive amount of choices in the Steam library.  Recettear is a mix between a Commerce game, an Action RPG, and a Visual Novel.  If you don't like one of the three, don't take part in it, that's what makes the game so interesting.  If you simply want to experience the semi-complex sales and marketting system, by all means.  If you just want to kill everything and earn money that way, that's fine too.  Maybe you want to just delve into alchemy and fusion; by all means.  Or maybe you just want to engage yourself with the deceptively unique characters that the game has to offer, you can do that (though it'd be rather difficult on its own).  This is the type of game that will definitely take a bite out of your life, and whether you are into Japanese games or not is irrelevant.  Recettear is a game that is what you make it, and let's you play the way you want to play, and it is certainly worth a play.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2011
												A really interesting and fun game. Kind of like a reverse dungeon game. Instead of going through dungeons being the primary focus, you run a store where adventurers will purchase supplies before going on their own dungeon adventure. You are, however, able to go into dungeons to find new items for your store, but the meat of the game takes place inside the shop, trying to sell items to customers. You want to make as much money off someone as possible, without making them feel like they're getting ripped off. Lots of fun.

Attempting to make as much money by using the resources you find in dungeons and to sell them back feels like a unique experience, and while it's a bit of a challenge to keep things going for each level, it rewards you in the cute anime style that this game is known for. content:
Posted: June 8, 2012
												This is one of the most addictive games I have ever played in my life. The first time I played it, I didn't stop for over 24 hours. Running this item shop is a lot more fun and rewarding than grinding for experience on Final Fantasy XIII: Corridors and Cutscenes. Don't be fooled by the Item Shop subtitle, there is still combat and dungeons, with some really unique bossfights. Has a new game+ option, and even if you get a game over, you can restart on day 1 with the majority of your progress retained. Buy this right now.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												I quite enjoyed this game. It's not as good as Kamidori Alchemy Meister, but who can compete with that right?The game is light themed, but at the same time dead serious. It's really easy to lose because you need to pay off your fathers debt and if you fail to pay the debt monthly (or was it weekly?) you lose your house and it's game over for you.This game is basically a collection of minigames, the focus of the game is shop management where you showcase your most valuable "shiny" items to lure people into the store and try to haggle it up to the highest possible price before selling it. But the worst thing that could happen to you is if you don't sell the item, that is you make it too expensive and the customer just leaves, so with that you need to learn what kinds of people are likely to pay more, and who are likely to pay less (for example, kids generally aren't very rich)Another minigame is "item gathering" which is basically just a 3D dungeon crawling minigame where you get to pick a character to play as and then dash through a dungeon crawling level. This again is not very easy and although there is no permadeath in this system, the death penalty is high. (Failure to gather valuable items and defeat bosses to earn these items, as well as exp can often lead to the game over screen)The game is a perfect mix of fun and hard with just the right amount of cuteness too.

												This game startled me. It just didn't seem like it'd be that much fun... I thought it'd be maybe kind of relaxing to run a shop, and that'd be the end of it.I was sorely mistaken.This game is just plain, downright fun. Frankly, I'm not entirely sure what's so enjoyable about it. The leveling system, the shop system, the integration of dungeon crawling and the item shop, the ability to switch back and forth according to one's mood - it just allows for a very relaxing experience, with just the right amount of emotional pressure, to make you want to really do your best.I've had this game for a couple of years now, and I keep coming back to it, every now and again. It's just... well, fun.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												Have you wondered what it would be like to run a shop as an anime girl in a Japanese RPG? If so, then Recettear: An Item Shop’s Tale is what you’ve so desired. And it IS an indie game, which again shows that, as usual, the AAA games industry can’t be counted on to touch the part of us which wants to play as a pretty little girl.One of this game’s taglines is “Capitalism, ho!” Recette, the protagonist and girl, says it with a big smile, and her eyes closed. Or maybe that’s how I remember her. With her open, maroon vest, green tie, belt buckle, and those two, large, red beads, maintaining strands of her caramel-colored hair in a tail beside her head. Plus that mortified facial expression of hers, whenever she hears opinions disparaging her business. She is so young.The game, though. There’s more to it than those tan sleeves, over arms which she keeps parallel to her sides, with her palms wide open, giving the appearance of an angel. There is, indeed, more to the game. For example: does she live alone? Sort of. She lives with a fairy. Her mother seems to have passed away. And as for her dad, he seems to have abandoned her, and with lots of debt. You must be the godlike father she evidently never had. You must take possession of her body and ensure she pays off her dad’s debt so as to avoid being dispossessed of everything except, perhaps, her clothes.Alas, that form of losing leads to one of the game’s weak points. For if you do lose (if you can’t pay your in-game debtors), you start from the “beginning,” with many of the advantages you’ve accrued in your defunct playthrough. This has you suffer what was already an uninspired dungeon crawler even more, as you’re sort of playing it all over again. It is by this and other means that you get to see little Recette running around, pit pat pit pat. By these you get to see her buy valuable items at low prices and sell them at high prices. You get to watch her go to sleep and awake, and reveal her innermost thoughts to her fairy friend. And it is all well-written, well-drawn, and….

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Recettear is quite possibly my favorite game on Steam.Concept: Your father ran away and left you in massive debt.  The collection agency sends out a fairy to get someone to pay up and that just happens to be you.  What are you going to do?  Open up an item shop in the middle of RPG-ville.Yeah, that's right.  Other suckers are out there killing for loot but you're chilling back in town playing the markets and raking in the dosh.  Buy your products from the guild or from the street merchants and turn right around to sell it to the townsfolk and the adventuring crowds.  Expand your store, learn the folks, and fleece them for every red cent they've ever made.Not exciting enough for you?  Want some action or maybe some rare items to sell?  Press those adventurers into servitude and hit up the dungeons for fresh wares.  Press on, gather everything, and keep it for yourself while the so-called heroes risk their lives for your profits.  Capitalism, ho!

												In this RPG-spoof-dungeon crawler, you get to play the part of one of the many shopkeepers you may remember passing by in any JRPG.  Somehow they managed to not only make a hilarious game, but also one with memorable characters, great shop-based gameplay, and a challenging dungeon crawler.  This is a must-play for any fan of RPGs who wants something different.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												This game starts out easy - run a shop, right?  And do a little dungeon delving on the side.And then things get serious!I waited a couple years for the sale price to be "reasonable enough" to buy it, but I think it's (at least) worth the 50% they normally put it on sale for!  It reminded me quite a bit of FF7, though maybe that's just because it's an anime JRPG.EDIT: The game is kind of a grind if you want to unlock the last two dungeons.  To do that, you need to play New Game+ 6 times!  That's actually not horrible (with breaks), since each adventurer is distinctly different from the others.  But then I couldn't make it to the end of the last dungeon - I think because of gear.  Getting the rarer ingredients for Fusion is such a grind that I stopped playing.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												The sort of game you didn't know you needed. Who knew running the item shop could be more interesting than being the JRPG protagonist? Well-balanced game elements, in a fairly addicting little package. Kuwai japanese voices, but that could probably be assumed from the screenshots posted in the store. Not especially difficult, if you keep your eye on the market, but lots of aftergame content and challenge modes to give it replayability. Pretty standard action-rpg outside the shop, but a polished generic RPG is what you'd expect from a game that's really trying to hijack rather than be one. Slightly oddball charicterization keeps you in the right frame of mind. A bit niche, but nails it.Capitalism, ho! (Frankly, that line is "Show me your moves!!!"-level quotable.)

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Never before have I played a game that I can describe as beautiful in such an eclectic sense. The town looks absolutely stunning on the PC. The story is rich and provoking, keeping you guessing and revising your theories as you play. The final scenes will haunt you, driving you (or at least many) to the forums to absorb and discuss thoughts on the plot possibilities. The music is captivating and enthralling, with all of its drama. With extra orchestral stabs to accent details such as how you finish an enemy, the experience really feels complete and integrated. The gameplay is familiar for fans of the previous Carpe Fulgur games, with new innovations to spice things up. Zipping around the town and dealing out devastating blows is both effective and immensely satisfying. No game is perfect, as no form of entertainment/art is immune to subjectivity but this game comes so close that it deserves a 10/10 for being worth every single coin spent on it.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
												An interesting mix of a shopkeeping simulation in a fantasy world with the added feature of being able to hire adventurers to go down into dungeons and restock your shop with newer and better items instead of buying them.Essentially you have three parts of the game - in your shop you can move items around, or swap them with your inventory to ensure your best and most profitable items are on the shelves (you generally can't sell items not on display so choose carefully), and then wait to see who comes in the shop and see if they want anything you have on offer. If they do you will get to haggle with them to try and eek out that extra profit if you think you can, conversely they will try and haggle down the price.In town you can meet all sorts of people - other merchants you can buy items from (haggling again, but in the opposite direction), the guild where you can craft items or also buy more stock, or the tavern and elsewhere where you can meet adventurers sometimes.Finally there is the action RPG dungeon crawler where you can persuade adventurers you have met to risk their lives getting you more stock for your shop, this is probably the weakest part of the game as the controls aren't great, the monster variation is quite small, although there are a few reasonably well done boss fights to open up new dungeons.Overall a great game and well worth playing, just don't expect too much from the dungeon crawling side of things, that is more of a chore than anything else. The story is fun and endearing, and it is interesting to be on the other side of things in an RPG for once.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												GLANCE RECOMMENDATION: 89% YES / 11% NOGOODIncredibly interesting spin of gameplay. You constantly buy/sell items out of your item shop, then fund adventurers to go dungeon diving for you (all of which you control). I haven't played a game so intriguing for quite some time.The characters are very likeable and varied enough to adadpt to many styles of combat for dungeon exploration.The selling/buying mechanic is deep and as rewarding as you are daring. It feels great to get a high sell combo.The dialogue is fun without being jarring, which is hard for a lot of translated games. They knocked it out of the park with this one.NEUTRALI'm not incredibly fond of losing almost everything if I die, which is easy if you're playing low defense heroes, but you get use to the hitboxes of monsters so fast this shouldn't be too much of an issue the first time around.It's understated how hard you need to work for sell chains or dungeon dive as far as possible your first time around. There's a good chance your first playthrough for the first month will result in a box ending.SUMMARYThis was the biggest surprise of the year for me back when I played it. An unusually fun game, interesting concept, great dialogue, tight gameplay, and an absolute mass of content for the price. I highly recommend this title for people wanting to see what owning an item shop and haggling gameplay feels like.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2012
												2 parts business simulator, 1 part dungeon crawler - if that idea appeals to you I cannot recommend this game hard enough. You take on the role of the Item Shop owner in an RPG based world and supply the adventurers and regular townies with much needed supplies of every nature.But it's not just about stocking your shop - because of course no one's going to pay sticker price for your♥♥♥♥♥♥ damn adventurers and their haggling. Warning: You may want to drown the Little Girl for never having any money ever.The smart store owner stock piles items when they're cheap and sells them when they go up in value, and if there are ingredients you just can't buy from your suppliers, well then it's time to hire a sell-sword (whom you equip and level up yourself) and kill some monsters in a nearby dungeon, complete with multiple randomized levels and some fun bossfights.Adorable art style, great gameplay, so simple and yet so much fun, easy to sink a ton of hours into. Happy gaming.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2013
												For the first 15 minutes, Recettear is a slog with it's sacchrine sweet animu story, music and characters.  The talking (and by talking, I mean reading) carries on forever as the stern midrif bearing librarian looking fairy lectures you on the ins and outs of being a child laborer/shop owner.  Then you finally get done with the lectures, you open your shop, you maybe go explore a dungeon for some items, and the next thing you now an hour has passed. It's a steep price entry, all that slow reading to kick things off, but once you get to the meat of Recettear, it's kind of charming.  The dungeon exploring (which you technically odn't even have to do) is not too shabby, set in real time instead of your typical turn based combat that japanese RPGs' tend to use.  Once you load up on items, you had back to your shop, put them up for sale, make a little money.  The haggling system seems kind of pointless, but you know...whateveer.  It's still enjoyable.  Not something I'd power through in marathon sessions, but if you can get past the tooth ache that the oh-so-cute setup gives you, it's an allright game.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2011
												"CAPITALISM, HO!"  Are you a bad enough dude to pay off your dad's loan?Yes, it's a game about working retail.  No, that doesn't mean it isn't fun.  Haggling with customers is surprisingly intense, since you have to balance the need to squeeze as much profit from them as possible to afford the next loan payment against the risk of them breaking your combo (robbing you of experience points for store improvements) by walking away from an insulting high offer.You can also go Zelda-style dungeon crawling as the adventurers whom you're selling all the equipment to, but that's a dangerously low-profit waste of time during the story mode.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												Not quite a RPG but still close enough and more importantly: great fun! What if instead of being the hero, you were the item shopkeeper, selling to and buying from adventurers?There's quite a bit more to it too, brought about progressively: negotiating prices, taking orders, managing stock, dungeoning with adventurers to get loot, changing your shop's atmosphere to attract different customers, finding new adventurers and learning about them and their backstories... It's a very cute game although prepare to see the dark side of capitalism if you fail to make your loan repayments in time ;)The demo is quite comprehensive and I heartily recommend giving it a try to see if you'd like the game.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												Recettear has a great amount of gameplay for its worth. Story is fairly unbelievable. A little girls father who has disappeared leaves his daughter with a huge crippling debt. She's only 10 (I am guessing?) how is she suppose to repay his debt? Why the fairy Tear tells her to make a store so she can pay it back. The lil loli Recette gets help and turns her house into a store. While the story was fairly unbelievable and lacking there isn't much to do but if you do the RPG dungeon part more stories unfold and builds up more character for Recette and Tear and the Adventurers. Characters in the game have a huge impact. Everyone is unique and different and the events that happen make them rememberable enough. The more you unlock the more events that will happen interacting with all the characters all together. It gives incentive to do the dungeon part of the game to unlock more of these characters with their corky bits and pieces. There are two different types of gameplay here. Running the Store and the Dungeon Crawling. Running your store was great but a challenge. Everyone has a different budget and you have to learn that by personality and age. The little girl is well in fact a little girl so she doesn't have much money. Louie is poor but the more adventuring you do with him the more money he gets and if you sell to him cheap he starts to get a bigger and better budget. It's so crazy and complex that each character in the game has specific things and goals and all this other crap that it's difficult to explain! Combat was simplistic but each Adventurer has their pros and cons and a different playstyle required. Not much to talk about here but it kinda reminded me of Final Fantasy without the turn base thing. Long story short, scamming off little girls or spent your life living in a cardboard box. Whats your choice?

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Racketeer - The game where you rip off small children and the elderly for fame and fortune! Capitalism ho!Seriously, you play a shopkeeper of a stereotypical RPG, catering to both the regular townsfolk, as well as the occasional adventurer.Oddly enough, the game actually has surprisingly good writing, with a unique and interesting assortment of eccentric characters set to a rather ridiculous plotline which works not just in spite of, but specifically because of how silly it is.A lot of various addictive qualities show up in Recettear, such as RPG-style leveling of your character/shop, an economy where you purchase materials and have to buy low/sell high, as well as witty and charming dialogue.You'll find a modest variety of characters enter your store; a small girl, an elderly man, a housewife and a generic common man for the regular townsfolk, each with their own personal buying habits. Toss in the more unique characters such as your brattish rival with a cynical faery of her own, a runaway princess-turned drunken assassin, a cyborg who is kind of new to the concept of "money", and a down-on-his-luck wannabe adventurer, to name a few, and you'll find yourself entertained for quite long periods at a time interacting with them.Haggling is an artform, and you get significantly rewarded for giving an offer that will be accepted on the first try rather than just going back and forth until someone either gives in or they meet in the middle. As such, there's actually some pretty shrewd tactics to manage when trying to haggle with customers, and learning their personal traits and spending habits can be quite beneficial.As a whole, it's a fairly unique game. There have been others vaguely similar to it before, where you buy low and sell high... but none which have have nearly as much polish and just sheer charm to the personalities you interact with in Recettear.Final Verdict:It's really quite enjoyable for what it is. If you like shopping, or even just anything similar to facebook or flash games, you'll probably adore Recettear. It's value for retaining a player's interest can be a bit less than ideal, however, as there is an "end" to the game. There are some nice options for increasing replay value, but you'll probably only find yourself doing one or two playthroughs every few years. It's a nice game to come back to once in awhile, but not on a consistent basis.Overall Score: About 80%. It's really probably the best game of it's kind out there, and the writing is great! The content duration's a bit short, though, and considering the game type... you might want to wait for it to go on sale; $20 is a little bit much. $15 is reasonable, and $10's a good, ideal price for it.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												You've got a loan to pay, but you're just a girl who's Dad has gone off adventuring... No worries, as an item shop, you'll be able to sell stuff to repay your loan! One problem though... Isn't that really boring? And you can't just sell apples 24/7... (Well, you COULD).When you're bored, or you want super rare items, what other way to pass the time than going into a dungeon! Slay monsters with dedicated Adventurers, outsmart traps and find the really expensive treasure!You decide the price the customer should pay, but if it's too high, they'll leave in a bad mood; too low and you're not making any profit (but you'll win a place in your customer's heart).Was the main story too easy? How about an endless mode where your loan just increases every week? How long will you be able to hold out?In my opinion, it's definitely worth the price.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												 Well, Recettear is a pretty good game, among them independent "doujin" games! In fact, it's really something with a unique twist to the dungeon crawler genre; YOU RUN AN ITEM SHOP TO GET OUT OF DEBT! The main character is a little girl named "Recette", and her father had left her to go on adventures, but little did that idiotic father know that her LITTLE GIRL GOT IN DEBT! And now she has a fairy companion, Tear, to help her get items, on her adventures, where she goes to gain items! (Kinda interesting, huh?) I reccomend this game, for one reason; the sense of humor in it is ABSOLUTELY HILARIOUS! I give this game a 4/5 rating, saying that this game is very unusual, but having to make an order is so frustrating, so I suggest doing it, when you can.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												You've got a loan to pay, but you're just a girl who's Dad has gone off adventuring... No worries, as an item shop, you'll be able to sell stuff to repay your loan! One problem though... Isn't that really boring? And you can't just sell apples 24/7... (Well, you COULD).When you're bored, or you want super rare items, what other way to pass the time than going into a dungeon! Slay monsters with dedicated Adventurers, outsmart traps and find the really expensive treasure!You decide the price the customer should pay, but if it's too high, they'll leave in a bad mood; too low and you're not making any profit (but you'll win a place in your customer's heart).Was the main story too easy? How about an endless mode where your loan just increases every week? How long will you be able to hold out?In my opinion, it's definitely worth the price.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												Well.... Where do I start. When I got this game I didn't expect much at all. But I have to say this game is AMAZING. I have played through the first 2 hours and I am enjoying this game immensely so take this as a first impressions review!Story:I won't go into to much detail in the story because I don't like spoiling anything in most games. Mainly you are the daughter of an adventurer and have to run a store to pay off your fathers debts who has disappeared. I swear they make it more immersive in the actual game.Graphics:I thought this game was going to be some very crap anime bulls**** dating sim and I am very happy it isn't. The graphics (from the point of view of someone who has never seen anime in his life) are good. I like the style and the cutesey mood and style of this game can from what I have heard be deciveing... (I really don't know though I am only 2 hours in.)Gameplay: This game is a type of RPG game that has a different take on it. Instead of being an adenturer and killing monsters, you own a store to sell things to people and adventurers, later on in the game you gain the ability to hire an adventurer to go into a dungeon and fight monsters to get loot for you. (The cool thing is you get to play as the person you hire giving the game variety and letting you kill monsters) More things might be unlocked later and I can't wait!All in all this game is a refreshing breath to the RPG genre and allows you to take it from a different perspective. I recommend you pick up this game even in full price. I will update my review (If I remember to) When I finish the game!

												This game too me a while to really master as I'm certainly not the best with my savings. However, what really helps is that when you are unable to pay a debt and have to start over, you get to keep your merchant level, adventures keep their levels, you keep the upgrades to the shop AND you get to keep all the items you didn't manage to sell, giving you the ability to bounceback much more!Not to mention the fusion ability is really helpful to gain some really expensive and unique items to sell to more effectively pay off that bill.The characters are a lot of fun with many interesting stories too going on around the place with many different and interesting mechanics going on too.  This is  alittle hidden gem that requires a lot more attention and I really love it! Capitalism, Ho!

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												So what is this game?  You run a shop to sell items.  You also go exploring and fighting in Dungeons to level up heros and find items to sell and craft with.  The game is a bit grindy, but the story was interesting enough, and even after one play-thru, I feel like I have yet to see half of the game.  Playing this feels like playing good old JRPG games, y'know, when they were fun and plentiful.I really did enjoy the humor in the game, and felt they translated it very well.  Recettear has a bit of a learning curve... but some good replayability to it also, from what I am seeing.  Twenty three hours in and finished Loop 3 as my first time win.  Would have won on Loop 2 but ended up being about 30k short...Anyways, the game is repetitive at times, but it always keeps you moving, so doesn't feel too bad.  The story in the game progresses in a linear mode, but seems you get additional story based on certain events/actions.  Reminds me a lot of older RPG's such as Chrono Trigger, where you may not see everything in one or two play-thru's and you need to search for those unlockables.Looking forward to continuing play and finding everything I missed.

												Good heaven's this is a great game! I beat it in 2 sittings because my 1st sitting went until 4AM and I realized that was no time to be awake! I love this game probably in my Top 10 games ever! great music, amazing writing, and the gameplay is phenominal! even the tutorial is nicly paced giving me some time to learn my new skill instead of piling on a ton of learning and wishing me Bon Boyage! only real complaint is that the game is too short... 2 sittings beat the main story but there's extra modes to overcome! also the dungeon crawling is a bit of a let down, don't get me wrong I love grabbing Louie and grabbing gear, but everyone but your 1st hero is abysmil, and only like 2 of the 6 dungeons are unlocked with in the space of the game, but the dungeon combat is fun and the bosses are challenging you have to use wit to defeat them...Tip: Buy high sell higher most items cost about 70% of their price and you can sell them for 130%... when an item becomes rare it goes for like 100% at market but in your store you can sell it for 275%-300%Great game I'm very liberal when I rate games but easy 10/10

												This is a simulation of a dystopian society where child exploitation happen.Your main character is a loli who apparently forced to enter a dark dungeon spanning from 5 floor down to 100 Floor or more to pay for your parents debt by a haughty debt collector fairy.The debt are hidden from you so you do not know the amount of the debt nor you know how many of the debt is real or a scam.Every week the fairy will force you to pay a sum of money or you will be kicked out of your only home left by your parents, and do not hope for government assistance because there is none.As a loli, you need make money and now as a player you will guide the loli how to make money effectively via capitalism.You will need to cheat and lie to customer to sell your item so you can have a roof.10/10 recommended for social studies

Otherwise, I wouldn't bother.

Posted: July 18, 2012
												Keeping this short and sweet.  The game is a typical hack and slash, yeah.It's got a nice, simple economic system and you run a shop, yeah.The dialogue has funny moments, yeah.And you're basically gauranteed the "bad" ending the first time through.And your main character is a psychotic loli. But you can turn her voice down. And there are a ton of recurring themes in Carpe Fulgur games.And I did actually play the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of this.And I am reviewing this because it is on sale with other Carpe Fulgur games.Imma sum those up quick.  Oh, and you NEED a controller for them or you're ♥♥♥♥ed.Chantellise: Balls hard.  Enough said.  Fortune Summoners: Kind of like Zelda 2 with 5 year olds and objectives that are about as easily to follow as Simon's quest (IIRC).  Decent combo system.Get them on sale if possible.  Otherwise, I wouldn't bother.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												I had loads of fun with this game! Getting the hang of the mercantile and combat mechanics was a nifty, goofy ride, and the characters and dialogue are adorable. By the end of the main story, however, I found that the store aspect of the game becomes rather trivial (buy everything under the sun, sell for moderate profit at the first opportunity, rinse, repeat). I also found it too difficult to finish the side quests necessary to recruit some characters before the end of the limited time frame. Still, I happily recommend it with thumbs up!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1
 Don't miss it if its on sale!Capitalism, Ho! It's a business management game coupled with dungeon crawling and boss fights. Challenge gets increased with time and dungeon maps are mostly randomed. You will get to the cute but funny storyline and be able to collect adventurers to hire as mercenaries through the game. This game has so many little complications and features packed in one. You are able to pimp your adventurers with gears of your choice. You are able to sell items at 200% their price. (The satisfaction!) You are able to go dungeon crawling to collect items to sell. (Hohoho, 100% profit!) You are able to fight bosses and get KO-ed (If you are noob). You are able to switch up the wallpapers and flooring of your shop to change its atmosphere.Cute characters involved. At some point, they will sound ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ though. (Makes it lighthearted~)Each villager who comes to your shop to buy items have their own individual budget that you need to note. Kinda makes the game more realistic if you ask me. You can't expect to sell a little girl a super highly priced item. All in all a pretty worthwhile game.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												Great and addictive RPG reminiscent of old school classics. If I had to compare it to anything, I would call it the Rune Factory (Harvest Moon with Dungeon RPG elements) of entrepreneurship. Anyone who enjoys a mix of playing through dungeons with a number of different heroes, each with their own specialty of skills as they level and weapons they use, and taking charge of a store to barter the prices of items you sell with customers should feel right at home with this amazing game. (I put about 20+ hours into it in under 2 days!)

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Sure, you can go into dungeons, beat up some monsters and steal all their loot, but it's much more interesting to play the item shop owner who's supplying those brave adventurers.Mechanically it's an OK game.  The dungeon crawling portion is serviceable, but pretty much any dungeon crawler would be better.  The economics/shop aspect is interesting, and it claims depth through the customization options, but I had no trouble finishing the game largely ignoring anything beyond the basics.  It's a good way to kill some time without thinking to hard, but if you're looking for a complex game you'll find better options out there.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Truly unique and excellent gaming experience.Recettear places you in charge of an item shop where you supply adventurers and other random NPC's. The shop management elements (from pricing to inventory to layout) are well thought out. But in addition to that there is the adventure. You can explore various dungeons along to find out a long forgotten secret as well as have fun with the various adventurers you have been equipping.The dungeon gameplay is simple action-RPG fare, but again very well balanced and a lot of fun. It is also one of the main sources of rarer commodities that you will be selling in your store.What might seem like a quick bit of casual fun will end up being a day long obsession. This game is highly addictive. :)

content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
												Recettear is an item shop management game that includes dungeon crawling, item fusions, and hero item management.  The ability to haggle with customers and handle their special requests ("I want a weapon!") keeps things interesting but the UI, menus, and controls can be a hassle.  The anime style and irritating sound effects do get on my nerves, but I did have fun playing this game in short bursts.  I wish it was more open-ended, but you have strict repayment deadlines that you must keep or else you fail.  Not perfect, not terrible, fun, but not THAT fun.  Recommended if on sale.PROS+ You get to run your own item shop!+ Gathering items to sell and equip via dungeon crawling is fun+ Haggling with customers and handling special requests adds flavor+ Leveling up heroes and upgrading shop keeps things interesting+ Lots of items to collect, fuse, sell, and equip+ Storyline might be interesting to some (I thought it was silly)CONS- Japanese/Anime style may irritate some (girly giggles and constant whining come to mind)- Dungeon diving is very basic and combat is relatively shallow- Permanently equipping your heroes is a chore (they have to randomly buy item in store)- Lots of pointless dialogue including tons of EH's, UM's, OH's, !!!!'s, etc.- Relatively linear due to repayment deadlines and ongoing storyline- Clunky controls and confusing UI make it seem like a simple RPG Maker game

												Do you like RPGS? Do you like interior decorating?! Do you like characters that are so stupid and cute that they just make you go "aww..." Then this is the game for you!One of the few RPG esque games where the main character actually does no fighting, Recettear is a unique gem in the gaming world that may never have similar opponent. Interior design elements, similar to animal crossing, and proper space management are the keys to your financial success on your way to pay off crippling debt! Hire friends/mercenaries to go into dungeons for you to gain stock and learn of their secrets...hah not really there's nothing that angsty in this game.Give it a go! Capitalism ho!

content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												I'm not sure what the appeal for this game is. I was looking forward to it so much after hearing all the hype and came away from it very dissatisfied with two half-baked systems that failed to engage me. The shopkeeping is fairly basic aside from a (simple but very fun, thought it was one of the best parts of the game) random price raising/decreasing. The combat is laughably simple. In addition, if you fail to meet your debt, you have to repeat the entire game. While normally I like the idea of devestating failstates in a game (really enjoying XCOM, for instance), I didn't really want to sludge through another bunch of hours of this crap. In addition, it feels like the game was designed for the player to fail once- unless you can beat the game on your first try, the only benefit that doing well on your first runthrough is that you end up wasting more time playing this game. The second try is almost trivial since you keep you entire inventory after the first failure.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												I can't recommend this game, and I'm sad about that.The cast of characters is quirky and fun (after all, "Capitalism, Ho!" isn't a meme for no reason).  But that's all there is - after the second week or so, I began to realize that the mechanics lack depth and the dungeons are repetitive.  Here's the long bit:I have many tiny nitpicks, but the one that is the easiest to point out is that in a haggling game, you would expect ... well ... haggling.  But there are no counter-offers - not even clever dialogue hints as to what price they're willing to pay (that I was able to figure out, anyway).  Instead, they tell you exactly how to beat the game in the tutorial - 125% for selling, 50% for buying (plus or minus 5%).  High price items will be 3x the base cost.  Low price items are roughly 1/2 the base cost.  The Little Girl can't afford anything.  Knock 10% off for heroes.And it never varies - if a haggling game makes me want to just put price tags out since there's no actual haggling involved, then its done its job poorly.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												The best game I have ever played in twenty years of computer gaming, bar none (and I have played a LOT of games). Eight years on I can still recall how profoundly that game gripped me, and I am not an overly emotional person. You will care about the characters, you will be moved, you will make choices that tell you more about yourself. It sounds trite, I know, but it really is that good. If only someone would make more of these...insightful, intelligent, devastatingly creative. Fallout is the only RPG to come close. A word of warning: You MUST read all the text, explore all the dialogue options, if you are to gain the most from the game. A decent intelligence and wisdom score is recommended.....although so is a decent score in everything else....the game does the best job of making usually superflous statistics genuinely useful that I have ever seen. Still very much worth playing.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												The best game I have ever played in twenty years of computer gaming, bar none (and I have played a LOT of games). Eight years on I can still recall how profoundly that game gripped me, and I am not an overly emotional person. You will care about the characters, you will be moved, you will make choices that tell you more about yourself. It sounds trite, I know, but it really is that good. If only someone would make more of these...insightful, intelligent, devastatingly creative. Fallout is the only RPG to come close. A word of warning: You MUST read all the text, explore all the dialogue options, if you are to gain the most from the game. A decent intelligence and wisdom score is recommended.....although so is a decent score in everything else....the game does the best job of making usually superflous statistics genuinely useful that I have ever seen. Still very much worth playing.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												I'd recommend this game to teenagers and under. I think that adults would get bored of this game within a few hours.You play a girl who has to pay off her father's bank loan, by working in a store ( buy low, sell high ) and dungeon crawling for items, to sell in the store. The retail aspect is as uninteresting as working in a real life, retail store. The dungeon crawling is a basic hack 'n slash and reminded me of Zelda ( without the puzzles ) this aspect is fairly fun.I paid $5 for this on sale, which is OK. I'd rather have paid $2.50 for it though. Definitely not worth any higher than $5.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												To call this game a pale shadow of Kamidori Alchemy Meister would be an insult to Kamidori Alchemy Meister's shadow.  While slightly entertaining to those who enjoy this type of game, it is deeply lacking in almost every aspect.  I would only recommend this to someone who is really interested after watching the trailers. Even then I would still say get Kamidori instead if you don't mind the sex scenes and know how to get the translation working on your computer.  Surprisingly bland gameplay.  Every aspect of the game I've seen is easily learnable with little to trip an intelligent player up.  I've played three dungeons, and beat the normal game in a single loop with about a million pix at the end.  I actually had to force myself to finish the game.  It was enjoyable for awhile, but the monotonous gameplay wares on you incredibly fast.  The dungeons are challenging, but not in an interesting way.  I am loathed right now to go and do more dungeons because it was so monotonous.  The dungeon bosses and enemies are all incredibly simple and each have a single trick involved in beating them which is almost immediately understandable as soon as you start playing.  They each have like two attacks which are stupidly easy to dodge.  The basic monsters aren't much better, they either throw projectiles, pop up in weird places, or monotonously jump in random directions.  The later dungeons did start to get challenging, but only because of the monster spam.  Item selling is probably the only area that this game excels over Kamidori in.  In Kamidori, you'd create items and just leave them in the shop to sell by themselves, in this game you actually haggle with customers to sell them items.  Theres a large array of gameplay mechanics behind it as well.  It does get old fast though.  In short, it's fun for a couple hours, then you just wanna be done with it.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												Conceptually very interesting, i won't deny they did a good job at making a management game revolving around JRPG characters in a JRPG world. Traditional to JRPG the story is going to be the most interesting part fo the game, unfortunately i'm downvoting because i found the game grindy and boring. I was constantly checking the marketplace only to be bored with zero encounters. The writing is silly cheesy fun, but can take forever and get on the nerves. The dungeons were painfully boring, dunno why they tried to shove an RPG into a perfectly good management game. Especially since the management itself isn't amazing, i feel like the game had a lot of interesting ways to innovate and explore. Instead EasyGameStation innovated a tiny bit, then all the dev power was put into the long dungeons enemies and loot art. I didn't come to reccettear wanting to play the dungeon crawly RPG elements, but i can tell that's where all the effort went, and it's the most boring part of the game. Though managing the shop is interesting and complicated I'd like a shop management sim with more refined features.

												Crazily overhyped game that *should* only appeal to kids and ultra casual gamers. May be good way to teach kids how capitalism works. There is really no challenge in this game. The story is simple. The mechanics are bland. The gameplay is super repetative. I was recommended to play this game after loving Stardew Valley. What a difference. They don't even offer a video resolution above 1280x1080. How this game has 97% positive reviews is beyond me. It's the first game I ever got a refund on.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												There's nothing blatantly wrong with this game. I bought it because I like simulators and I like RPGs. This seemed like a great mix of the two. I found myself rather bored with the characters but I wasn't expecting a deep plot to begin with. While in the shop and selling items to customers, the same generated no-named characters come up and ask to buy certain items. I was hoping the customers would be people you may know from in town and grow a relationship with over time.I also wished you could customize your shop but it stays exactly the same, along with your characters' dress. There just wasn't enough compelling content to keep playing.Try the demo before buying it.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												A sweet little game on the facade, but pretty much unplayable without a spreadsheet open. By the time I had finished the game, I completely gave up on the RPG aspects and I had the numbers on the spreadsheet memorised. I also had a notebook open listing all the orders and the days on which to stock up items in my shop ... Essentially I was running an actual business. There's a few things to love and I genuinely enjoyed my experience, but when it comes right down to it, it's just not very fun for most people. Maybe if the spreadsheet was in-game and there wasn't a random NPC that breaks all your combos and you had more incentive to do the (surprisingly well-made) dungeon crawling, it'd be a great game, but as it stands now, it's just for the type to optimise numbers and people who love CAPITALISM (HO)!

content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												When i first tried the demo for this game i thought to myself i can really get into this so i picked it up during a sale happy with my purchase. However after putting in a few hours with this game there is a fundamental issue with the mechanics that ruin this game for me and force me to not recommend it.Now although its fun setting up your shop and adventuring in the dungeon for items to sell the game neglects to mention a major mechanic in the game that can actually make the game unplayable at times. The tutorial simply tells you that what you wanna do is buy items from people at 50% and sell for 130%. Fair enough and pretty straight forward. After a while however i started to notice that 130% was out of the question and even 120% would drive customers away. I would lower and lower the prices and still drive customers away at 90% and even 80% of the base cost. BUT THE TUTORIAL TOLD ME 130% WAS THE MAGIC NUMBER! I took to the internet to see what i was missing and what i discovered was the game fails to mention there are two invisible stats that drastically effect gameplay. Customer loyalty level and customer budget. Customers would come in trying to buy items they didnt even have the budget for no matter what price i set them at and then would leave mad which lowered their loyalty and budget even more. By week three the game was unplayable. Now i could probably easily start over fresh with new found information about how the budget and loyalty stats work but do i really wanna have to take notes while i play. keeping track of invisible stats the game never mentioned to me to make sure i didnt try to sell items my customers will never even be able to afford. Invisible stats ruine this game for me.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												This game could be fun if the engine wasn't designed in a so unacceptably bad way.Every day I started this, the controls randomized themselves. One day O was my accept-button, one day it was square and one day it was triangle. (Using standard PS4 controller with DS4Windows which works flawlessly in all other games).Using the configuration tool that comes with the game does not help at all (it mixes up your controls even more and you end up accepting by pushing left etc). The max resolution is 1280x960. That may have been good in the year 2000, but it's 2016 now and this game really looks bad at 3440x1440. If you run it windowed you have to use third party software like ShiftWindow to force this thing into borderless mode. It won't take over your window-resolution but stay at 1280x960.There are many options in the config tool that let you downgrade the graphics to i386-niveau but nothing that actually lets you improve it. I think my graphics cards didn't even wake up from desktop mode while displaying this thing at it's max FPS of 60.All in all this game, albeit being a PC only release, feels like a super bad console port with Consolitis so strong, I'm surprised it doesn't infect my other games. Apart from the technical amagheddon that this thing (I'm not calling this game) represents, it can actually be fun. I will not go into those details as it's simply not worth playing for a PC gamer. I can write mods for Skyrim and fiddle with NWN 2 configs for days but I simply don't see why I should endure the unwillingness of devs to create a remotely playable game on the main game platform: the PC.1/10 - not even playable.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												The object of the game is to acquire a certain amount of money by the end of the game's month in order to pay your rent. What an exciting concept for a game!Money is earned through one of two ways, either going into a dungeon and killing things to get money and things to sell or by playing the shop-keeping minigame.  You buy supplies from other vendors and than try to sell them to random villagers.  This consists of sitting around and waiting for a customer to come into your shop and than haggling. Haggling for 20-30% higher seems to be the best so you just do this all day.   It's as braindead as it sounds.    It's as braindead as it sounds and the only real challenge is to avoid falling asleep.   Sit at the counter wait for an npc to walk up to you, set the haggle amount to the same value you always use and press the confirm key, repeat until credits roll. The good news is it's pretty much impossible to lose doing this so your boredem ends quickly. There's only about 5 different looking shoppers that come in and each only has about 2-3 lines, being stuck in the same room with the same npcs is nausiating.  I should mention that this is the core of the game.  The dungeon crawling stuff is better buy actually getting to it is hidden behind annoying crap where you need to talk to some random npc after doing some obscure task on a certain day in order to even unlock the ability to go into them.  There are several characters to play as in these sections and they all require a different find the npc puzzle to get. In addition each dungeon must be unlocked by yet more tedioum.  The dungeons themself are short, offering nothing interesting, with boring enemy design and gets repative really fast. The quality of the dungeons and combat is comparable to freeware flash games. Since the object isn't to clear the dungeon but to grind everything feels unrewarding and tedious.  You'll probably want to do this rather than the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ shopkeep mini game but gives less money for a higher risk and requires you to spend half the game talking to npcs to unlock dungeons. This isn't a serious game and has no bussiness charging $20 or even $2 for what is essentially a flash game.  The only people that like this are♥♥♥♥♥♥eating weebus that have no standards and will play anything with an underage anime girl.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2016
												For starters, I do not think this is a bad game, but it is definately frustrating. If you are not a patient player, you will hate this game. First thing I should point out is that you will be micro managing every single transaction, if I knew that I would never have bought the game.A lot is lost in translation from japanese to english. There is no instruction on which keys to press, you have to figure that out on your own. I have learned that button 1 is "z" and button 2 is "x", I have not been able to determine button 3. The entire game revovles around item value, but does not let you organize items by value. On top of the lacking features is a convoluted tutorial on gameplay and mechanics that is 90% useless banter trying to be cute and entertaining.The dungeon runs are repetitive, and you'll find yourself spending more time back tracking to areas you have cleared to kill a single enemy that has respawned, just to get halfway back to see that it has popped up again on the minimap(then repeat 4 times).Then there are the transactions, which are also repetitive. Shortly into the game they will throw in people trying to sell you items, which would be fine, if you knew they trying to sell it. I can't tell you how much money I've lost buying items that I thought I was selling.Bottom line, although I mildly enjoy this game, I just cannot recommend it.

You had said that you saw no difference between economic power and political power, between the power of money and the power of guns - no difference between reward and punishment, between purchase and plunder, between pleasure and fear, between life and death. You are learning the difference now." - John Galt
