content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												I had really been looking forward to this game... but after completing it, I'm sorry to say that I cannot recommend Recettear. You expect there to be more when really the game is pretty shallow.The Ragnarok Online-ish graphics got me hooked at the start and I liked the no-nonsense dungeon crawling and the shop aspect.. but there's just not enough here to keep you engaged. Or if there is, the game is not organized in such a way that you can enjoy it without a guide.First of all, the dungeon crawling gets really repetitive. Fighting doesn't require you to be clever, because you're OP all of the time. After you unlock your fourth and final skill on a character.. you switch to a new one because they just get stale.Worse, dungeon crawling is actually detrimental to your progress, because you rarely find items worth the hassle, but you lose 2 units of ingame time that you could have spent selling stuff in your shop.The shop system's got a tutorial that makes you haggle with your customers, although suggesting a price they'll like is the only way to get combo bonuses for selling, which are more useful than the extra buck from high sales prices.I also found it very, very difficult to survive the debt cycle (someone in the comments even asked "So did anyone survive the first round?"). When you can't pay back your debt on time, it's not a complete gameover, but you start again from the beginning, only you keep the items you have in stock and your merchant level (that gives you access to more stuff on the market + other stuff that helps). The second time around is too easy. I finished the last ingame week doing nothing but killing time and still had 1 million pix when I payed off the final debt of 500k. This should be more balanced.The crafting system is a nice addition, but suffers from a lack of menu integration. You literally have to write stuff down you want to hunt for in the dungeons. Would have been much nicer to be able to pull up a menu and see "Aha. I need 2 more pieces of X to make Y." That's why I ended up using it just to make stuff I had randomly collected the ingredients for. It's very inconvenient.Sure, I could have played it smarter and looked into a guide to make lots more money by crafting. But honestly? When hunting for the items isn't fun.. why would anyone bother?All in all, I don't really want to drop a huge pile of dung on this game. It has its enjoyable aspects, but as it is, I just don't think it'll be fun for you. That's why I'm not recommending it. If you like, you can play the demo. But don't expect much more than the content you see there.

												Schmooley Benjamin Kippelfinkelburg ben Shekelstein was not a proper Jew, and could not fulfill the role of his ancestors in serving as a source of legal credit for French nobles and royals seeking to fund their personal ventures via circumvention of Church authority.Amassing significant debts on his (loaned) property after the subprime mortgage bubble bursted in 1599, and lacking even basic skills in the trade of counting shekels, he set out to make his fortune, only to die somewhere in the mountains offscreen, leaving his only daughter, Recette-Anne Frank Shekel Israel Lemongrass ben Shekelstein, to inherit responsibility for virtually all of his debts. The rabbi of the city's quarter, Isaac Schlomo Goldstein Shekelburg ben Levi Abraham Cohen, on behalf of the Goyim and with the help of the cult of Satan and the blood of seven gentile children, then invokes the Kabbalistic Sephirot to summon a Jew fairy, of whom is promptly dispatched to Recette, both to collect the outstanding debts according to a strict timetable, and to teach her the art of counting shekels, stowing gold bricks under the floorboards (and in the walls), acquiring the role of an extremely convenient scapegoat, and shortchanging customers like a proper Le Happy Venetian Merchant. Loli Jew Recette learns to contradict basic merchant guild regulations in 17th-century France, engages in the unholy act of ritual blood libel during Passover, exploits her incompetent Swiss mercenaries by paying them to risk their lives picking up valuable consumer goods in the dangerous wilds (and then reselling said items to those same people at a profit), and invents the free market and 9/11 in the process. You'll have hours of fun wondering where in your house you hid all those millions of shekels (called "pix" in the English translation) prior to the game's start, as well as by selling candy to the goyim girls and that one Irish elf for the equivalent of a small fortune. If you can't make your payments on time, however, the rabbi will charge you a pound of your own flesh per shekel as collateral, effectively making your life forfeit if you fail to live up to proper Mosaic community standards of personal and fiscal responsibility within the quarter.9/10 shekels plus one pound of flesh/10.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
												I picked up this game at some point in the past based on what I saw of it.  But when I launched it, I was in for a big surprise.  The game comes up as a window, with no option to be fullscreen.  It very handily (and I mean that sarcastically) offers 3 oldschool menu options, and a nice title screen.  Only there's no way to tell what the keybinds are, and you're going to need them because the ♥♥♥♥ing mouse doesn't work.Under Display (Menu option V?), I'm offered some meager choices that let me increase the display size by percentages.  Yeah, that helps, just increase everything in 50% increments.  Who needs display resolution when you've got this?  The "Help" option very helpfully told me what version this game is.  I don't know about you, but when I think about needing help with a game, I secretly just want to know what version it is.As far as the rest of the game goes, I'm not sure. With the controls being the utter ♥♥♥♥♥how that they are, I'm not going to waste more of my time.Maybe it's better with a controller.Steam is asking me if I recommend this game.  Since I don't see a "♥♥♥♥ NO" option, I'm just going to choose no.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												NO SPOILERSI don't understand how this game got such overwhelming positive reviews. The game mechanics are horrible, trash infact. The game developers had a great idea or concept for a item shop game but the systems and implementations are utter garbage. The story made me genuinely laugh out loud at times, but I would have rather watched the story unfold like an anime tv show then play this game, in fact I ended up going to youtube just to see how it ends. Without going into details, the story is your usual young-teen-hero-anime show story with some fourth-wall breaking stuff about video games. However, the story is not good enough for me to want to continue to play the game just for it. The mechanics are so clunky, repetitive, and downright head scratching it makes me wonder why I bothered to put in 12 hours. I think I did only because of the overwhelming positive numbers making believe that this must be one of the best games ever...however it is far from even being an average title and I do not recommend this game at all.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
												This game is a cute, clever idea. That's it. Everything else about it is, well, to put it gently, not good. I get the feeling it would play better on a moblie gaming device like a PS Vita or 3DS, but as a PC game it flops. Yes, I can re-map the controls, but the menu system just doesn't work with any configuration on the keyboard. Or at least any I've tried. I just... can't play the game to get a better feel for it. I lasted 84 minutes, but a lot of that was spent in the tutorial and in cutscenes. Actual gameplay time I got through was about 30 minutes. And then I just had to stop. It it a point in it's favor that it's not an expensive bad game, but that still doesn't completely absolve it of it's faults. It would've been okay if it was at least funny-bad, but no. This game if frustratingly bad.

number of helpful: 4 of 17 people (24%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2016
												I like the idea, i like the atmosphere.But the way the... campaign is done is just no fun.Ignore all orders.They will just take up time and when the items are less worth at the day the order is to be sold (wich happens randomly) you are tough out of luck and have lost money AND time you could have served another customer wich means you have lost the possibillity for two sales all in all. Never buy from the guild. Get ready to grind, grind, grind, grind, GRIIIIND your local dungeons. You can hire several heroes to find items in those dungeons. Except you never use anyone else but the hero you started with because by the time you meet others that hero is level 28 and up because of all the grinding.Only put out your most expensive wares. You can't really... "roleplay" if you will, a balanced shopkeep who wants to serve all kinds of customers. If you don't put out and sell your most expensive♥♥♥♥♥♥you are ♥♥♥♥ed and can start all over. On top of that you need luck, luck to get the right items, luck to guess the prize right and the right adjustments wich can just be all ove the place when dealing with customers.  The crafting system is also rather useless because of these elements of luck. I am 12 hours or something in and not once have i had any of the necessary items in the neceessary amount to craft a new item. It also would probablybe a waste of time and ressources because you CAN NOT AFFORD to play around with any of these two.You need to put out♥♥♥♥♥♥(wares) and get in money.After you have lost once you will realise that you need to keep the pressure going. The pacing just leaves no room for any elements that would be fun. And this is why i stopped, because i realized five days before the 200.00 bucks payment that i am not going to make it unless i grind the boring dungeons like a madman and ignore all the fun bits.This is what ultiumately kills the fun in having your own Fantasy RPG Item Shop. No one wants the grind from the joblife in his free time.

												I normally really like shopkeeper games but this is not much more than a visual novel. Adventuring is a repetitive hack-n-slash, though I enjoyed the bosses. number of helpful: 16 of 47 people (34%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												Before I start, I actually have about 6+ extra hours on it already, having played this game previously on my girlfriend's computer, so my current time on time spent playing this game isn't exactly accurate. I have to say I love this game personally. It's cute, fun, and addictive. It's probably my favorite that I have in my steam library right now. That being said, this is one of those situations where I wish steam had a "meh" button instead of simply recommending or not recommending a game. So here's the way the game works. (only game mechanics, no story-spoilers) The item shop gameplay is pretty simple. Buy low, sell high, try to make enough to pay off your debt each week. You're restricted on the amount of actions you can do each day. This whole part of the game plays like one of those in-browser flash games. That isn't exactly a bad thing as a whole. The art style is pleasing to look at enough to keep you playing and the game still feels rewarding when you actually figure out how it works. As the game adds more and more to the way the game works, it becomes much more interesting and challenging to play.There's a kind of dungeon-crawling mode in which you can use to find new items to sell, and I'm betting this is where players really spend 80% of their time. Some commenters say it's too easy, but I disagree. It took me five failed attempts to escape from the first, easiest set of dungeons. You can only escape on certain floors, if you 'die' you can only bring one of your treasures back with you, and the monsters that spawn are very annoying. All of this creates incredibly difficult combat for such a pleasant game. Honestly I love that as well. The maps, simple enemies, and very simple combat system remind me of a top-down version of Dark Cloud. The dungeons are painful to get through, but it's  also nice to see a game that occassioanally throws sand in your eyes, instead of easing up. It's something I'd expect from a 10-20 year old combat game, rather than a modern seemingly-casual capitalism sim. It's still fair and I can't bring myself to blame the game for my failures in the dungeons. Now for the negatives. Once again, the combat is very basic, your enemies are very basic, and well even the shop management is simpler than it could've been. I think that do it well, but it does leave you wanting a bit more. A huge issue I have with this game is the translation company, and I originally intended to avoid buying this game for myself at all. First, the translations are just awful at some points. Maybe I'm just too aware of linguistic issues to overlook it, but there are *so many* moments where the word choices just scream "look at my creative translation, isn't it cool?", when many other translations would've fit better. The point of the translation is to draw attention away from the language use, to forget that the material even came from another language in the first place so you can focus on the story, but when they use obscure words like "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; or made-up words like "yayifications", you're no longer experiencing the story of Recette but having it told to you through an amateur translator. It's really difficult not to get immediately pulled out of the immersion in the story. There's at least one positive aspect of the translations, in that however distracting their translations may be, at least it does fit the characters' personalities. Still, such a half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥job makes you struggle to maintain your investment in what's happening in the story.The second issue is that Carpe Fulgur (the company that translated this into English) has a reputation of changing parts of the story in the translation. The idea of a localization is to best adapt the game to the target region, but the changes they make seem to concern things that have no real legal or social ramifications in the first place. The fact that these changes are unstated makes me lack trust in a faithful, in-tact representation of the game's story and dialogue. This is why I was content to avoid giving them any of my money. I only bought it myself for two reasons. 1: It was on sale.2: I'm learning Japanese so I might as well practice using this game on my own computer. I don't really plan to run it in the English version at all.To sum it all up+addictive, fun+challenging yet simple and fair-shoddy translations work-questionable business practices of the distributor, thus untrusting that the game was localized as intended.If it sounds like fun, more power to you. But the negatives, at least in principle, are enough for me to warrant a downvote. At least until Steam adds a "meh" button.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2013
												Based on good reviews in PC Gamer, I bought Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale on sale and gave it a go. Although I am charmed by the idea of an RPG from the perspective of the shopkeepers in town, I find this game to be a poor experience. Managing your shop is awkward and tedious. Walking about town to get stuff for your shop is tedious and artificially slow. Bartering with your shop customers is a repetitive exercise. Adventuring in the dungeon to get stuff for your shop features laughable, simplistic gameplay mechanics.And the cutscenes... oh the cutscenes. They go on forever, padded with juvenile humor. You can't mash the button fast enough to get through them. I really wanted, and expected, to like Recettear more than I do, but I'm just not feeling it. I suggest finding a gameplay video before purchasing Recettear.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												The game does present itself correctly...you run an item shop.I suppose when I saw the game and some of the features it looked like it had Action-RPG elements that seemed more fulfilling than I thought it would be, so after playing for a while the game took a disappointing turn quickly.You play a very rudimentary High/Low bartering game that gets choresome and repetitive quickly, and occasionally delve into a "dungeon" for a few floors taking control of a hired mercenary with a primitive top-down action system...whose game you'd rather be playing if it weren't for uninspired dungeon floors, poor collision hit boxes and the slow grind for random item drops as you look for each floor's exit.There's very little sense of direct advancement, and a desperate disconnect between the gameplay modes with a very shallow playspace in each that leaves you feeling like you are stuck between a watered down simulation game and a watered down secret of mana with no will, motivation or desire to continue in each.The art, however, is fantastic and deserves to be commended...though the story acts that draw out the monotony between segments and the horrid anime whinings leave much to be desired and drag the game to a slogging crawl filled with ear-piercing howls.I do not reccomend this game, it suggests a broader, grander experience than it eventually delivers which tricked me...don't let it do the same to you.

number of helpful: 13 of 48 people (27%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale is probably the cutest worst game there is. Ill-conceived better covers it: you play half the game as a top-down dungeon crawler and the other half as manager to the eponymous item shop, with neither halves being properly implemented in the first place. I get the feeling that the developers, EasyGameStation, had very ambitious ideas for the concept of "Item Merchant Game" except that they've botched everything until what they made barely resembles a game anymore! I'll explain...You are Recette, spunky little girl entrepreneur required by the faerie bond collection agency to raise enough money to repay her father's exorbitant adventuring debt. For this task you have your house located smack dab in the middle of RPG City, which you've converted into an Item Shop for the convenience of all. Sell items to the roaming adventurers, make a profit, repay your debt; simple enough, right? It all goes to pot with the whole bargaining system and the complete lack of player feedback other than win/fail.Before that, an egregious crime in game development: having the tutorial LIE to you. When faerie sidekick Tear tells you that selling at around 121% of base price is a conservative strategy, she is flat out LYING to you. This is far above what many villagers can afford and will not increase important customer loyalty. This is especially villainous considering there is no other way than trial-and-error to determine a customer's comfort range.The process of selling and bargaining for optimal profits and customer loyalty is stupid and punishes experimentation. Any experimentation in bargaining reduces important customer loyalty which reduces the overall money pool they're willing to invest in your products. Worse, it's all so incredibly MOOT!!! When you buy goods from the guild merchant, he sells it to you marked down from base price. Therefore if you sell those goods at base price, you make a (small) profit. Base price is a perfectly good baseline for most customers and you can repay your debts out of this practice! Otherwise, use a strategy guide to know optimal salesmanship builds as there's no rhyme or reason to the whole process!Dungeon crawling is the second half of the game and although mostly innocuous, doesn't introduce any elements anyone would deem "fun". You hire an adventurer from the pool of friends you've made and go down randomly generated levels, looking out for monsters and treasures until you discover the exit. Inventory space (bag space) becomes the most annoying aspect as you're stretched between saving space for treasures at the expense of bringing food, rings and adventuring gear. Because the adventurers don't bring their own gear with them; no, that would be too simple! You have to sell them the stuff from your store, except you have no control over what they ask for and you can't "suggest" goods either. Egregious crime in gaming #2!All that said, the Main Story is fun enough. You have likeable characters, humorous dialogue... You really can't fault the English publishing company Carpe Fulgur for anything. It's New Game + that becomes a pain because the challenge comes from grinding for rare items (in multiples, for completion of the Fusion Recipes) and the fact that the dungeons are just longer with cheaper boss fights. Oh, did I mention that you can't save inside of a dungeon? There's really nothing to gain from the New Game + experience except an increase in frustration and maybe two characters. I put a point in saying maybe because if you do unlock the final character, you've already defeated all the monsters and bosses the game has to throw at you. That's bad pacing right there.The main problem with Recettear is that the item shop game, billed as its selling point, just doesn't work. It fails from lack of options for the player, lack of interface telling the player what he's doing right and wrong and arbitrary levels of contentment amongst the customers. It's not hard, far from it! It's that there's no gaming elements related to the experience. Recettear might as well be a visual novel with a dungeon crawler tacked on to it. It's cute and endearing but it fails at being a game to begin with. And I'm the idiot who gifted this product to so many of my friends. Just enormous waves of regret all around, don't be like me and get suckered in by a cute exterior...PS: I really wished that there were more "Adventurer" customers and less normal looking villagers, so you could really make this game about an ITEM SHOP SET IN AN RPG WORLD. As it is, you're really more of a goods store selling general products and knickknacks.

Posted: March 9, 2013
												Receattear has you play as a young chick fending for herself with a massive debt to pay off.And no, she doesn't pay it off that way. She runs a local store!This game is super fun and *incredibly* addictive. When I started playing this, when I was off work ill, I played it non-stop, and actually dreamed about it for a bit. It gets into your brain.The mechanics, however, are quite repeatative, and the process of acquiring items for your store is very tedious. The story, though, is charming and enjoyable (if you like JRPG sorts of games, you will appreciate it).My main criticism is that after 10 hours of play, I failed the game at the last hurdle, after being asked to complete *an impossible challenge* (I think it is anyway). The only way I can deduce to complete the game is to play it *twice*, and fail the first time. You prepare tonnes of items in the first play, really good stuff, and sell large the second run through.This, to me, is incredibly annoying game design, and is the reason I have not completed, as I refuse to put myself through another playthrough. For this reason, I'd avoid it, but if you can put up with that, then go ahead!Nilesy

number of helpful: 3 of 25 people (12%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												The story and art of the game is decent, but the game's underlying repetitive and counter-intuitive mechanics are ultimately unsatisfying. You might expect that in running an item shop your goal might be to buy low and sell high. However, this is only a minor element. The item shop gameplay is about learning the X % amount above the item price each customer will pay. This is in order to get a continuous "combo" of sales. Try too hard to make a profit on one item by forgetting that the “Girl” customer magic number is 115% of the sale price and you are punished - the combo is broken. "Capitalism Ho!" – Definitely not. These factors are compounded by the fact that if one does not quickly embrace the combo style of play (all about remembering X % amount for each customer) it’s likely you will have to repeat the game to complete it. The real kicker is you may not realise that you have to begin again until you have played through several futile and dull days. Ultimately, the playing experience was unsatisfying and unrewarding.

number of helpful: 8 of 37 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2012
												Recettear is a game that should be fun. You run an item shop, you quest for new items, and sell those items to people. Along the way you make friends and a pile of money. Simple enough to grasp, or so I thought. This game is so needlessly filled with dialog that it takes away from the fun. I'm all for a tutorial or a few helpful hints, but after 40 minutes of playing I hadn't even opened my shop for the first day yet. All I was doing was reading dialog AND not good dialog. It's not like there is a story line that will keep you on the edge of you seat. You are a young and very ditzy girl who is partnered up with a loanshark fairy. The fairy tells you everything you need to know to run a shop. She tells you, then you repeat it back to her and make a ditzy joke to go along with it, then she reiterates, and you make another ditzy joke. This goes on for far too long. The cyclical dialoge continues to ruin the game throughout. EXAMPLE: Fairy: "To get out of item select, press the B button."  Girl: "But I don't have a B button. Does that mean I'll never get out of item select? tehehehehehehe."  Fairy: "No, you will be fine, just remember to get out of item select, press the B button."  Girl: "OKAY! But if I find a B button I think I wouldn't know what to do. tehehehehehe. But you're the boss I guess. tehehehehehehe."Once you get through the 40 or 60 minutes of dialoge you get to actually play the game. This game is about questing for stuff. You play as another person, not the ditzy girl, and go to dungeons for loot. Then the girl you're playing takes all the stuff the other person you were playing worked so hard to get and puts it in her shop to sell for profit. Combat is a slight choir as you and monsters can move 360 degrees, but you can only attack in Up/Down/Left/Right direction. This means to attack something you have to line up to it, then move to attack, and then attack. It feels like it's been ripped straight off a Nintendo 64 title, and makes the combat more choir-ful than fun. All that being said, if you skip every bit of dialoge, and don't mind old-school controls, there is a little bit of fun to be had here. However, I in good conscious can not recommend this game to any of my friends.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												You can't save mid-dungeon, and it's very unforgiving. If you're looking to play the game how you want, maybe buy and sell, you can't. You have to dungeon crawl. Every day. The combat is fun, but the range on the adventurer's weapons isn't what you think it is, and the enemies are larger than their sprites appear to be. The first adventurer you get is very slow, too. Time your swings well. If you die you lose all the items you collected and even brought with you, save one.Running the shop would be fun, but customers have a set price range in mind (it differes depending on their sprites) and if you get it right on or close to what they want you get a bonus. If you get it wrong they're likely to walk out and you only get so many sales a day.Don't even think about selling expensive items early on either. No one will be able to afford them. They'll just get angry with you and waste a customer spot.I'm sure the game gets fun further on, but I haven't been able to earn enough money to make the first week. Nor have I beaten the first boss. Not for lack of trying, I've restarted four times.It seems like a casual game. It's not.Oh, and use a gamepad. Keyboard controls are awful.

number of helpful: 4 of 28 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												Don't buy this game. If it is offered for free, ignore it. It’s a meaningless dungeon crawler with annoying characters, a setting that fails to impress, and broken controls.PREMISES AND PROMISESBeing a fan and veteran of RPG-style games, I got excited when I read about this game. Instead of playing a hero, collecting loot and experience, you are a shop owner said hero would encounter on his travels! Very original.You play Recette , a girl who is left with the family shop after her dad suddenly leaves. He leaves a heavy debt too, and if not paid off, Recette will lose the shop and probably end up under a bridge in a box. She gets help from a fairy named Tear, who wants to see the debt being paid off because it is her company’s money. She is basically this game’s tutorial/faq.So, how does this all play out? Read on…TIME FLIES WHEN YOU'RE HAVING FUN… AND ALSO, WHEN YOU'RE NOTThe shop you run can sell weapons, equipment, potions, and sometimes more esoteric stuff. It attracts villagers and heroes both, and keeping them happy is the goal. Well, not the ultimate goal, but if your customers aren’t happy, they’re not likely to return and buy more.You can make your store more attractive by decorating, and can eventually make your own items when you get certain recipes.Before you can sell items, you need to buy them yourself from other shops, or you can join a hero on his/her travels in a dungeon and keep the loot that he/she finds (for a price). Then you have to place the item(s) in your shop, open your shop, and wait for customers to come by.There is a reason why I listed all these actions separately: everything you do in this game takes up time. As you have a limited amount each day, you need to know in advance what you want to do that day.This time limit forces the player to focus only on the goal of getting enough money to close the current chapter (with more money needed every following chapter). You don’t have time to take it easy: every part of the day must eventually lead to an increase of your cashflow.Unfortunately, this creates rather frustrating situations. For example, you want some good-selling items, as the deadline for the current chapter is coming up, but cannot buy them from a dealer (not in stock, or too expensive). So you venture into a dungeon, slay enemies, and hope for good drops.If you’re unlucky, you will only get bad or cheap items. So, you lost time for that day with little or no advantage. Now you need to get lucky in the store while selling the items and hope to haggle in such a way that you gain at least enough money to cover the costs for visiting the dungeon.This counts more towards having a customer wanting a specific item: he places an order, and you need to get it before he returns. Guess what happens if the item simply won’t drop, or can’t be found somewhere else!You cannot do anything about this “luck” factor, or plan ahead or around it. This gets increasingly annoying throughout the game, as you start to feel the game is deliberately taunting you. Speaking of annoyances…WHERE IS THE MUTE BUTTON? OR RATHER, ANY BUTTON THAT WORKSRecette is an non-assertive girl, has no confidence in her abilities and doubts herself every time something bad happens. This translates to annoying remarks, especially during haggling. For example, a customer comes in and wants to sell you an item you don’t want. The only way to not buy the item is to bid a very low price, have the customer disagree, and leave. Recette will always say something along the lines of “I have no talent” or “Can I really do this?”.It undermines the action and result of the player’s choice, and I got increasingly agitated with it.When dungeneering (not a word, get with it), Recette cannot stop asking the hero if he’s all right after he gets hit. Every single time. EVERY. SINGLE. TIME. Why is this necessary? Why does she need to ask?And boy, are you going to hear it often. The controls in the dungeon feel stiff, and despite seeing your hero hit an enemy, more often than not you will miss the creature, and get hit by it instead. Some enemies have such erratic patterns that it is almost impossible to predict their actions. Some enemies shoot fireballs that track the hero wherever he is, and will almost always result in a hit. Enough hits, and the hero gets incapacitated, you lose the items you collected so far, and you lose the time without getting anything in return.CONCLUSION: A BROKEN PROMISE, NO CASH RETURNSRecettear is a broken promise, like finding a shiny, round object on the beach the size of a high value coin, but discover it to be a worthless bottlecap.Too bad Steam won’t take it back, and now it just sits in my game-list, uninstalled, a constant reminder that an original story combined with a favorite game genre doesn’t automatically make for a good game.Gameplay 4/10The original setting fails because of its poor execution. There is no depth to the gameplay, as the player is forced into actions by the game, instead of controlling the game himself by his own actions.Graphics 8/10A nice manga-look. Colorful, and easy on the eyes.Sound 1/10Boring and repetitive, and you want to shut off the voices after a few minutes in.

number of helpful: 0 of 19 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												I like the alternative take on RPGs, where you're cast in the role of the shop owner. The thing is, this is still an RPG at the end of the day as you have to dungeon crawl to get the best loot to sell at your shop.The nail in the coffin, though, is that there's no way to lose. If you fail to make your weekly repayment, you get sent back to day 1 with all your stock, the adventurers' levels and equipment, and dungeons unlocked. It seems exceptionally difficult to actually win the game in one go. I guess you could just manually start again. The game seems designed for it to require several "loops" through the system to beat it, though, which is kind of bulldust. I want a challenge I can fail at, not a grind that I'll eventually get through no matter what.The thing is, it appears that the way to win is just grind, grind, grind in the dungeons to get the rare ingredients you need to craft high quality goods, because they're pretty much the only thing that'll make you enough money to make your repayments.  There's probably no game mechanic that sucks worse than grind, and it does suck a lot of the fun out of this game. Worse, the drops are random.I'm not much of a fan of RPGs to begin with, but at least you control the adventurer rather than issue them instructions, so it's your skill rather than their skill points that matter. You still need to equip them, but it makes sense that equipment is front and centre in a game about selling loot.In the end, it's a fairly bland RPG with a cool trade mechanic that gets totally upstaged by the dungeon crawling.I find the saccharine anime characters grating, but if that's your thing you'll probably like this.

												Only two games come to mind when I think of "Boy, I regret spending even just 5€ on this♥♥♥♥♥♥quot;, which are the horrible port of Saint's Row II for PC and Recettear.It might start off adorable, but you'll find out that it's ultimately a very shallow piece of software that gets insanely repetitive very fast.The dungeon crawling is also subpar and uninspired.I can't see anybody but people that "enjoy" stultifying grinding in MMOs playing this for more than a few hours.This seems acceptable for a 1€/$ tablet game, but it's absolutely inexcusable for such a, relatively, pricey PC game.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												I really liked this game it made sense and was having fun playing it.Then day 11 happened and the game threw out any resemblance of fair mechanics.First off the buying and selling system is broken.No matter my reputation at selling things dirt cheap people still come in expecting me to sell something less then regular price.It makes absolutely no sense that on day 10 I had no problem selling things for 130% mark up no problemo then the next day I have to beg someone to buy something for 103%Not only that the highs and lows is useless because no matter how much it says something is in demand no one will come in and buy the supposedly in demand item.Then when you do manage to get the person they refuse to buy your product for anything less then 100%I'm sorry old man I cannot sell you something for less the I paid for it because debts.I had precious metals decrease in price so I went and bought every metal item I could.The next day apparently there was a boom in metal items.I did nothing but run the store and for all 4 selling periods all people did was request hats. Not HELMETS, hats.Then when it wasn't hats they were trying to buy my yams for way less then what I bought them for.Its complete madness.Not only that but sometimes you screw up and need to restart the game and play a new playthrough.While I hope you like tutorials because prepare to be stuck with Tear holding your hand.

content:
Posted: February 6
												I bought this hoping for a pure, market, game....Stardew Valley but replace the farming with being a store owner.Instead I got a game with Gameboy Advanced controls (and look). A looming debt that has no reason to be there, and actually can scare off a good amount of players. Graphics so bad (mainly the monsters) that it makes Temple Run look like Batman: Arkham Knight. (Some could like this) A trial and error system that cannot be avoided. And the story follows like a bad anime or a kids book, again, why there's a story, I have no idea!But due to the fact that it's a small dev team like every other "Mosty Postive" indie game, people don't want to give it a bad review cause "it's the best they could do!"No, they could've made a better game, with possibly LESS resources.Remove the story, fix up the dungeon to look good (make the monsters 2D), remove the debt.Personally, I don't like it.BUT, if you are a person who likes the cutsey story/characters, and don't mind a trial and error system, then go ahead I guess, not sure what you'll like, but try it. Just, get it cheap.

												Its sorta like a shop simulation game in its own league. You get items from dungean raids and sell them in your shop to pay off the condemtion of your own house to your fairy "companion" who of which is extremely bossy and naggy. However if u have a weak heart i wouldnt recomend looseing and yes you can lose, just dont meet the required amount of gold on ur bill and you will lose and dear god the loseing ending always breaks my heart. Its also realy easy to lose in the game too because its a time based system and you have to do stuff at a certain time or you will screw up the whole game. Its literaly a hassle to do stuff in it too like making the time to go to a dungean..."OH WAIT its already night time now i cant put up shop now THANKS GAME!" but the game in itself is great for me sence i love simulations and anime combined so i would recomend for the average otaku.

												Omg, this game is so addicting and fun. Sure, the music may sound and feel a little corny or too anime at first, but it will grow on you after a few hours of gameplay. The item shop theme is incredibly catchy and you'll find yourself having it stuck in your head for hours too. Despite the game's cute appeal and animish appearance, it's not an easy game at all. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												I'll be simple here.This game is a store simulator with a simple (but engaging) dungeon mini game.The dungeon part does NOT have to be played but it will make the game last longer and you'll end up having more fun!And items... Free items! You unlock character as the story progresses. These you can use to venture into dungeons and level up, get new equipment for etc etc. But mainly they come buy their equipment in your store so try not to rip them off or they won't buy!It's not the most easy game though it's pretty basic. You have to pay debt ever week and it goes up and up and up for 5 weeks. So it's not a surprise if you'd have to start over a few times. HOWEVER, you get to keep your current items and levels for your adventurers which should make it easier to actually beat the game. Make sure that you continue from your current save file and do not start a new game from the menu or it's back to the very start.The story is nice and cute, nothing too special but enjoyable. So are the characters, I can't say I liked them all equally as much but you won't pay TOO much attention to them while you're selling stuff anyway. There is a small craft part to the game aswell. Don't overlook that as it comes in handy when you pick up low value items... Which... become more valuable as you craft them into something nice obviously!In the end, this game took me about 20hours to complete at a slow pace with alot of dungeon runs (some of which have failed), 3 restarts at an early level and while reading all text. There is also an endless mode, survival mode and new game + to extend the fun of the game should you be into that.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2013
												Have you ever wondered what it's like to own a shop in an RPG world? Recettear will let you fulfill that wonder.When you first see this title, you immediately think "some japanese anime thing". Well, I do have to say you're right.Despite the appearance, Recettear is a great dungeon crawler as well as economy based game. Characters are voiced by japanese VA's, but can be muted. OST is a little generic, but doesn't take away from the game. Characters are witty, and the MC is adorable. Overall, if you love some RPG elements, and dungeon crawling experiences, you surely must pick up this game!!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 18, 2010
												Do you enjoy the quirky characters in JRPGs like Disgaea?  Do you like dungeon crawlers?  Do you get a rush out of hoarding money in RPGs?  If you answered yes to one or more of these, this game is worth a try.Developed in Japan by EasyGameStation and localized by Carpe Fulgur, in this RPG you take control from an unlikely main perspective - that of an item shop owner.  Experience what it feels like to be on the other side of the counter, as you haggle prices to sell everyday items in an effort to turn a profit.  Your goal: to repay the debts left by your father, a careless adventurer who wandered off and got himself killed (naturally).However, "buy low, sell dear" isn't the only thing to do.  There is an entire dungeon-crawling sub-game within Recettear, in which you can hire an adventurer to guide through various dungeons, gaining experience and picking up loot along the way.The mechanics overall are simple, but fun, and potentially addicting.

												Recettear is a great game both in artwork and in content. It can appeal to a lot of people due to the way you can acheive the objective in the game; paying off the debt of your father, by running an item shop.Recettear incorporates dungeon-crawling in a game where you ordinarily wouldn't see something like that, but it only serves to enhance the game, rather than drag it down. 												One the most fun games I've seen in quite a while,a game that explore a rarely touched aspect of RPGs and do so very well.PROS:* well-designed trading system with a lot of depth to it.* a simple yet fun combat system that doesn't overshadow the main focus of the game.* very good writing, made me genuinely laugh more than a couple of times.* the goals system is pressuring but not actually too hard, and very different than the dangers depicted in other games.CONS:* ranged attacks only fire in four directions, wouldn't hurt in a turn based system, but that is not the case here.* while the goals are manageable and generally a good feature, it leaves little room for the experimentation I feel needed with such a unique game system.* lack of camera control in dungeons, not too bad but sometimes items/enemies get behind some of the scenery and its kind of annoying.in short, not perfect but tons of fun and highly recommended.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												Silly me.I felt that item shops in games were tedious and suited the purpose of step-leveling players. It often gave the illusion that such purchases weren't compulsory and that success depended not on your inventory but on you, the hero. As machines of hand-holding patronization I utilized them like a good wank and moved on, not fulfilled but satisfied that a purpose was served. They were a function, not a feature, of video games reality.I've played MMO's for a few years. I always hated the Auction Houses, the Trading Plazas and the player economies in general. Because of my disdain for the enterprise of digital enterprise, I would undercut constantly. Nubs would praise their providence at my rock bottom prices while gougers and manipulators would curse the minor chore of buying and flipping it for a higher price while sometimes haranguing me for being self destructive. ~~My eyes are open and I repent!~~Now, as the proprietor of an item shop I feel the pressures that my disregarded digital counterparts felt. Why the heck do you want a hat every GD day grandpa? What is with all these innappropriate books you reading little girl?  Aw nuts! Price on daggers just dropped? I just plotted my upgrades and don't have inventory space to do this flipping right now! It helps to think of them all as players on some tedious quest out there, in some awful task based world where they simply trudge through a series of completionist mediocrities that amount to a few clicks echoing in a tiny corner of the vast space which has become my mercantile empire! These beasts of burden, these movers of product whose true purpose is to fill my storage room with oddities and my pockets with power! My precious little clients with their oh so similar faces and quaint but repetitive stories. If I had a dollar for every bumpkin whose family wanted them to pick up a piece of candy for dinner....wait...I do sorta. Never underestimate a housewife? HAaahahahahahahahahaaaa!10/10 would experience cathartic megalomania again

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												If you've ever played an RPG, chances are you've visited the ubiquitous Item Shop. There's one in every town, city, and sometimes dungeon. And rather than play a dungeon-diving hero, you play, well, the shop keeper. Who's rather cute and adorable, if a bit naiive and too prone to puns and tropes. And speaking of tropes and puns, the entire game itself is a pun on RPGs in general. The game isn't fully-voiced, but is voiced enough that it shouldn't matter. What Recettear really comes down to it is this: If you love accumulating wealth and stuff in video games almost more than the game itself, then this game is for you.Just don't die in the dungeon, you really can't take it with you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 10, 2012
												Not a new game, but brings a fresh new play to RPGs if you haven't been playing this type of game.  It still of course, has action RPG elemnts where you can hack your way through dungeons, but the main game mechanic that this game is focused on is maintaining an item shop where you can sell your spoils to adventurers!  Where you used to play as an adventurer in RPGs, and constantly visiting a shop or two every chance you get--now you get to BE those shops! The main goal is ot earn a certain amount of income each week to pay of debt that the main character's father had left, paying it incrementally.  The amount to pay eac hweek increases as time goes on.  You collect goods to sell by buying from your customers (after level 2), buying from other shops, or going through dungeons and grabbing any loot you can get.  After you get goods to sell, then you can arrange them in your shop!  If yu can earn more money, you can even  customize your shop to fit your needs.If you love RPGs and management style games, then you should totally check this out!  DOWNLOAD THE DEMO NOW, DO IT!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 31, 2013
												A dungeon crawler through and through with the added element of cold, hard, capitalism.  You take up the role of a young girl named Recet.  Her father has gone off to become a hero and leaves her to live on her own.  One day a fairy named Tear shows up and announces that unless the loand on the house gets paid the bank is going to repossess it and Recet will be kicked out onto the street.Tear comes up with the idea of having Recet open an item show and thus Recettear is born.  The game is centered around paying down the debt in installments that get bigger each month.  It is quite easy to miss a payment and have to "loop" into another attempt.  When you loop you keep everything you currently have (pix, items, state of the shop) but you start over from day 1 and your adventures are set to level 1 and you have to reattain them.After completing the game there is also an endless mode where you can continue playing the game and unlock new dungeons.If you are a fan of JRPGs this game should be an instant buy for you.  Even if you are not I highly reccomend it.  9/10 stars.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 5, 2012
												As an economist and nerd, I knew I was going to pick up this game eventually.  Not many people consider what goes on in the lives of RPG store-owners, and this game attempts to address that.  The story is entertaining enough, and for those who don't like business management as much as I, adventurers can be hired to go on dungeon crawls.The game has a few flaws, though.  First, the loan payments go from challenging to excessive too fast, and then stop way too early.  After that, the entire reason to earn money goes out the window (aside from some optional modes).  Second, while the dungeon crawls are fun, and can be rewarding, they take so much in-game time that you're almost always better off just running your store, and going to the guild or market when your stock is low.Still, you'll likely enjoy the game if you have even a bit of interest in business, so it's worth purchasing during a sale.

Well, wonder no more as you take the helm of a fancy-pantsy item shop and sell everything from apples to swords. But wait, that's not all. Don't wanna pay for your merch? Well, just head off to a dungeon and get some stuff for free! 												This game was shockingly fun.  It's a twist on the old linear RPGs.  Instead of the hero, you're the item shop owner. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Recettear is a must! If you separate the management part and the dungeon parts there's not much new to it. But, together it makes a really fun, refreshing and addicting game. The progress you make is rewarding, The tutorial is skippable (something a lots of game could use but don't), the animations are great. The mixt of 2D and 3D can be a bit weird though but you get use to it pretty quickly. I love that they kept the japanese voices it adds to the experience of the game. Recette the main character is adorable even when you know there's an evil capitalist hidden behing that cute face. The gameplay is smooth and intuitive. The dungeons are a bit repetitive, but they're still fun and they complete the management part amazingly well.The big weekness of the game for me is the adventurers you unlock and pick to do the dungeons. I almost pick the same adventurer (Louis) every time wich makes the other adventurers pretty much useless to me. I switch from time to time but there's some adventurer I don't have fun playing like this guy who's a melee fighter and TRIES to punch his way through dungeons wich really doesn't work for me when you can just use the guy with the sword who got a way better range.Apart from that, it's a great game. Tons of hours of gameplay, cute japanese characters, overall fun and rewarding, if you're not convinced yet just try the demo!

Posted: September 3, 2013
												A game about a cute anime-style girl left to pay off her father's debt to a loan shark by running an item shop. Half the game is a dungeon RPG, where you gather your inventory by contracting adventurers. This part gets a little tedious, as attacking and defending doesn't feel very good with this game,  and enemies don't seem very inspired. You want to maximize your time spent in the dungeon segments on training your adventurer, and then come home with good loot, which you can only carry so much of, for your shop. The other half of the game involves running the item shop- selling stuff, haggling with customers, leveling your merchant skills, and praying the little girls go away. Capitalism, ho.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 8, 2011
												Cute, addictive and wonderful Capitalism. There is so much about this game that makes it wonderful. From the dialogue to catchy tunes all the way to it's bartering system. This game will suck you in and keep you dungeon crawling just to make a few more pix.You play as Recette Lemongrass. A cute little anime girl who runs an item shop! One day her father decides to become a hero and head out on an adventure. Little does she know she will receive a visit from Tear, a small fairy that arrives to collect on a massive debt her father left her! As you might have noticed the name of the game is Recettear, which is also the name of the shop, a combination of Recette and Tear to show their partnership to pay off her debt.There is two parts to Recettear, running the shop and dungeon crawling with a hired adventurer. Running the shop is rather simple. First, you need to stock your shop with goods. You can either purchase items when they are on huge discount from other shops in town or hire an adventurer to find loot in the various dungeons. Different customers will come in and each one has a different amount of funds as you will learn over time. This will help you in your selling and haggling once you realise this!Never go over the 130% markup unless the item has a massive price boost from low supply in town.As each week begins, you will have a certain amount of pix (money) you need to make in order to pay back your father's debt. Each week it will increase, which is the challenge, and failing to have the amount for Tear will result in End Game. The plus side is you start over with the pix you had when you failed! (also unlocked dungeons)As for the dungeons themselves there is an Adventurer's Guild in town where you can recruit someone to venture into dungeons to gain loot. These tend to fall into the warrior / thief / mage class set and require certain items or events to happen before they will be unlocked. Soulblazer (Super Nintendo) comes to mind when I think of the dungeons and combat. It's very straight forward and never terribly difficult to get to the end of. Keep in mind you can only stock twenty items per trip!All in all, it's a cute little game that can be highly addictive. It's got amusing dialogue and loveable characters. It can easily be picked up incredibly cheap during any Steam Sale. Do yourself a favour and pick up this little gem!

												A fun little game to play with. You run your father's item shop that serves the townspeople and various adventurers, and if you fail to pay off your father's debts, you lose the shop and end up on the street. Lots of ways to earn money, whether strategically buying items low and selling them high or recruiting adventurers to go dungeon diving for loot (these segments are playable, and aren't terribly deep but they're kind of fun).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												What a surprise, I've read decent reviews about this game in the past. Playing the game itself turned out to be a much better experience for me. The dialogues in the game are very lighthearted and expected of JRPGs, and it works for this special blend of RPG. The gameplay mechanics of upkeeping your storefront, and dungeoneering are simple and effective, and fun! It is repetitive work, but also methodical and makes you want to try to figure out the best play style in earning as much cash as possible within the shortest amount of time. That's how I look at the endgame, get all items and earn as fast as possible. 8/10!

												Experience what it would be like to be a shopkeeper! If you were also a little girl. And if you had a fairy helping you. And if you had to start your store under crushing debt. It has a small learning curve that leads to playing for hours just selling items in your store. If you get bored of that, go out and adventure in a ranomly created dungeon. You can beat the game without doing anything but selling, but dungeon items are almost pure profit. I'd say most of the game actually starts after you beat the main game and enter endless mode. That's not to say that the race against the clock to pay off your debt in the main game isn't fun. Bottom line: this game is awesome to no end.Capitalism ho!

Posted: July 26, 2013
												"It's like an anime version of those ♥♥♥♥♥♥ dinner dash games, only it's good."A charming, sweet game with quirky characters and solid mechanics.The game isn't really lacking anywhere, the story is interesting, the shop's management is engaging, and the dungeon areas are properly entertaining. Whether you're new to this genre or have played these sorts of games many times before, you can still enjoy it and not feel too over or underwhelmed. Pros:- Eye-candy ageless graphics - Easy to pick up after long breaks- Moderate-high replay value- Voice acting- Good amount of fun random events- Characters control extremely well- New game +- Pacing is good and doesn't turn into a 'waiting game'Cons:- No real challenge to keep the shop afloat during mid-late game.- Dungeons are somewhat repetitive- No difficulty settings- Kind of buggy, mostly in NG+- No real learning curve

												Recettear is a really well made game. It is very fun to play, you have the option of running the shop, dungeon crawling, or visitng the town to buy things throughout the game. 												GOOD: -nice idea to mix a shop with dungeoning.-nice playable characters with good characterization.BAD: -The ideas about the shop management are enjoyable but soon after a couple of hours we already have seen almost everything about that content and we already know most of the % for the child, the old guy, the man, the woman and the guild guy...-Dungeons too damn repetitive...this is something expected when are involved randomized dungeons, but they could have add few more traps or "events".-They could have added a combat more enjoyable...after a while it gets boring to use just attack or skill 1,2,3.-Story too linear and to know all of it you have to beat an extra dungeon with 100 lvls that it is just too boring.-The last extra dungeon is quite useless and there is not real motivation to finish it-They could have added more content to give motivation to the player to play it after finishing it.PRICE: Worth 5/7.5 euroRECCOMEND:I do not reccomend to buy this game if you want to do only the shop management since it gets easily boring, while i do reccomend it at those who like to farm endlessy dungeons with little changes and with attack + skill.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 22, 2013
												It's an RPG that stresses earning money and shop mechanics more than exploring it's world and characters. You are supposed to earn enough money to pay off increasingly larger amounts of debt, but this only encourages grinding at your store. You can leave the store with a hero character and explore a dungeon to gather treasure. This mode plays like an Zelda on the SNES, top down action combat, but unlike Zelda is straight up combat with only three special abilities per character. When your doing nothing but it for 5-10 dungeon floors against the same old slimes, pumpkins, bats, and what the ♥♥♥♥ ever it gets boring and tedious fast.  Also with a limited space of what you can take back to sell I found I had to be constantly managing my inventory, but that crap is with all RPGs. There is also a crafting system for more valuable items, which means more dungeon grinding for ingredients. But under the fixed time constraint to earn money, it's very possible to ignore. Only the first 10%-20% of content is introduced by the game, the rest you have to♥♥♥♥♥♥around to find/ start the unlocking events. Upon finishing paying off the debt, I had only unlocked 2 dungeons and 2 heroes, out of like 8 dungeons and 9 heroes. According to the wiki and realizing the amount of grinding to unlock it all I realized my patience with the game had worn out. TL;DR : Beating the game by grinding the first 10%-20% of content isn't fun now is it?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 22, 2013
												This game is much better than I thought it would be. You play as Recette, a young girl left to pay off her fathers debt. You have to open up a shop so the loansharks don't take your house. While owning the shop is important you must also hire an adventurer (who you can also control) to go out and find treasures in dungeons and defeat challenging bosses. All the treasures you manage to loot during adventure can be sold at your shop. After buying/selling items and bartering, each week you must reach a set amount of money otherwise it's GAME OVER! Definately a worthwhile purchase especially if you have a low budget but want to try out a new game. The graphics are simplistic, the music is fitting and the characters are relatable, all the little features make this game great!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 2, 2012
												   Very fun RPG where you take the roll of an item shop keeper.  While sitting around hawking broadswords all day may not sound very fun, the shopkeeping element is oddly engauging and surprisingly deep - with different customers having behavior quirks and fluctuating budgets, mechanics that reward a concientious approach to pricing (the most someone will pay for an item is not always the best price to sell it for), and different ways to sell items including advance orders and vending machines.  If you ever get bored of the daily work grind, however, you can always hire an adventurer and spend the day exploring a dungeon for exp and loot (which you can, of course, sell in your store for 100% profit)     Lots of postgame content (there will be entire dungeons and playable adventurers you wont even see on your frist playthrough). Worth $20, but a definate pickup on its frequent 50% off sales.  Play the demo.  9/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												Recettear is a game that represents a solid concept executed at a barely adequate level.  Amassing items and wealth is gratifying, but the game seemingly goes out of its way to keep you from feeling like a true weeler-and-dealer;  your character's plaintative whine whenever you walk away from a deal (even if it was a guaranteed money loser) is grating and goes against business sense.  The top-down action stages are minimalist and, while a diversion from the usual process of running your shop, grow tiresome rapidly.  To cap it off, the game is so aggressively ~uugu kawii Anime~ that it's hard to concentrate on being a retailer.That being said, why would I recommend this game?  Succinctly, because it's a solid idea that begs for greater resources and a more elaborate execution.  How much you will enjoy it depends upon how strongly you feel the urge to become your very own pawn star.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
												I recommend this game 8.5/10 worth the price, worth the time: I would like to talk about dungeon crawling, selling items, story and endgame content:1) Dungeon crawling is fun at first but becomes repetitive to farm for item crafting even though there is a mode called boss rush that makes it easier to farm. Becomes tedious. 2) Selling items is the most fun buying things at a low and selling high. However, it's likely that you want to get xp from selling the item in one go without 'haggling' the price as shopkeeper - this is limiting factor for maximising profits and deters you from 'haggling' the price as it offers little reward other than few % of money. Haggling is optional but causes a bit of disadvantage in exploring the games content as through leveling you unlock more features but haggling will take significantly longer to get xp. 3) The story is pretty cute and diverse, there's events that happen right until the end of the game. 4) endgame content are survival mode, new game+, exploring events and filling the excyclopedia. However, I didn't play past the main story because the gameplay got repetitive after losing twice, however if you didn't get bored then why not? It could be better but is good as it is. Thus 8.5/10.

												If you've ever played an RPG you're familiar with the concept of an item shop: a convient place for players to pick up gear and anything else they'll need in the game, with ever-increasing prices from the shop owner that keep you grinding away for cash to buy things with. In this game, instead of being the adventuer, you're the shop owner. I bought this game becuase it looked cute and might kill some time in the afternoons. Instead I got a very challenging RPG experience and some of the most fun I've ever had learning economics and trying to find the balance between running my store and dungeon crawling. If you're a fan of RPGs or JRPGs this game is well worth the price for all the enjoyment I've gotten out of it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												When I first played this game it was with mouse and keyboard.  Big mistake.  Now that I have a controller the game is much more fun. The game premise is simple: buy low, sell high, pay off weekly debt.  There is a simplistic top down dungeon crawler in here too, but it's surprisingly not necessary to finish the game.  You can easily "win" by buying items from other vendors, or even customers, on sale and then marking them up when the prices rebound.  There is a bit of store "management" as far as expansion and decoration, but I couldn't tell if it made any sort of difference.  This is definitely "sim-light", but it's charm and simplicity make for a casual and relatively relaxing experience.  Recommended if on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												This is the kind of game you would consider buying during a decent sale but probably not willing to do a lot of research, so I'm looking to keep the review very concise for those people. This is a great game. That being said, it is a very niche game. It satisfies a gaming itch I´ve had for years. If you enjoy management games and RPGs, this game is a very well executed mix of the two. The game is charming and addicting, albeit a bit shallow. I enjoy the game's simplicity at first because it allows me to enjoy the most basic pleasures of management and shopkeeping, but my interest began to wane near the end of the game. The combat is basic and unnecessary, but entertaining enough. The story takes roughly 10 hours and is quite satisfying. The game has close to no replayability even with "New Game Plus" because the management system is very basic. It's a good thing the game is a story based and not a SIM, because it won't hold your attention any longer than it intends to. It's a great 10 hour experience. Worth 5-10 dollars.

												Yes it's an anime-styled game. If you don't like that, stop reading here.Yes the graphics are very nintendo-wii-esque. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 14, 2012
												One of the unique games out there. It combines a little trade simulation and some top down action combat in one game with a little bit of Text-Adventure. You run a little item shop. To sell items you venture into dungeons. You then decide which items you sell and which you eventually wear yourself. Whether you sell crafting items or use them to craft new items. You set a price for an item yourself and can haggle with your customers. And you can even take errands from your costumers. You can invest your hard earned money to improve your item shop or save it up for the ultimate goal which is to pay off the debt your dad made.I love this game because i like the idea of managing an item shop. It makes a lot of fun to decide thinghs like which item i should put on the front window (to attract people which pass by) and which on the shelf. To see them come into my shop and watch them look around and make me hope they have interest in the items i previously found in a dungeon.

Posted: August 1, 2013
												Recettear is a great game both in artwork and in content. It can appeal to a lot of people due to the way you can acheive the objective in the game; paying off the debt of your father, by running an item shop.Recettear incorporates dungeon-crawling in a game where you ordinarily wouldn't see something like that, but it only serves to enhance the game, rather than drag it down. The spoils of your dungeon-going can be put on sale, thus bringing you closer to your goal.While sitting in your shop selling things to people might get boring after a while, the repetativeness is interrupted by new people appearing and new events happening. Overall, it's a wonderful game. Even the music is great! I would definitely recommend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												Silly me.I felt that item shops in games were tedious and suited the purpose of step-leveling players. It often gave the illusion that such purchases weren't compulsory and that success depended not on your inventory but on you, the hero. As machines of hand-holding patronization I utilized them like a good wank and moved on, not fulfilled but satisfied that a purpose was served. They were a function, not a feature, of video games reality.I've played MMO's for a few years. I always hated the Auction Houses, the Trading Plazas and the player economies in general. Because of my disdain for the enterprise of digital enterprise, I would undercut constantly. Nubs would praise their providence at my rock bottom prices while gougers and manipulators would curse the minor chore of buying and flipping it for a higher price while sometimes haranguing me for being self destructive. ~~My eyes are open and I repent!~~Now, as the proprietor of an item shop I feel the pressures that my disregarded digital counterparts felt. Why the heck do you want a hat every GD day grandpa? What is with all these innappropriate books you reading little girl?  Aw nuts! Price on daggers just dropped? I just plotted my upgrades and don't have inventory space to do this flipping right now! It helps to think of them all as players on some tedious quest out there, in some awful task based world where they simply trudge through a series of completionist mediocrities that amount to a few clicks echoing in a tiny corner of the vast space which has become my mercantile empire! These beasts of burden, these movers of product whose true purpose is to fill my storage room with oddities and my pockets with power! My precious little clients with their oh so similar faces and quaint but repetitive stories. If I had a dollar for every bumpkin whose family wanted them to pick up a piece of candy for dinner....wait...I do sorta. Never underestimate a housewife? HAaahahahahahahahahaaaa!10/10 would experience cathartic megalomania again

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 8, 2011
												Cute, addictive and wonderful Capitalism. There is so much about this game that makes it wonderful. From the dialogue to catchy tunes all the way to it's bartering system. This game will suck you in and keep you dungeon crawling just to make a few more pix.You play as Recette Lemongrass. A cute little anime girl who runs an item shop! One day her father decides to become a hero and head out on an adventure. Little does she know she will receive a visit from Tear, a small fairy that arrives to collect on a massive debt her father left her! As you might have noticed the name of the game is Recettear, which is also the name of the shop, a combination of Recette and Tear to show their partnership to pay off her debt.There is two parts to Recettear, running the shop and dungeon crawling with a hired adventurer. Running the shop is rather simple. First, you need to stock your shop with goods. You can either purchase items when they are on huge discount from other shops in town or hire an adventurer to find loot in the various dungeons. Different customers will come in and each one has a different amount of funds as you will learn over time. This will help you in your selling and haggling once you realise this!Never go over the 130% markup unless the item has a massive price boost from low supply in town.As each week begins, you will have a certain amount of pix (money) you need to make in order to pay back your father's debt. Each week it will increase, which is the challenge, and failing to have the amount for Tear will result in End Game. The plus side is you start over with the pix you had when you failed! (also unlocked dungeons)As for the dungeons themselves there is an Adventurer's Guild in town where you can recruit someone to venture into dungeons to gain loot. These tend to fall into the warrior / thief / mage class set and require certain items or events to happen before they will be unlocked. Soulblazer (Super Nintendo) comes to mind when I think of the dungeons and combat. It's very straight forward and never terribly difficult to get to the end of. Keep in mind you can only stock twenty items per trip!All in all, it's a cute little game that can be highly addictive. It's got amusing dialogue and loveable characters. It can easily be picked up incredibly cheap during any Steam Sale. Do yourself a favour and pick up this little gem!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												Overall this title is a enjoyable game. Although it wasn't $20 origionally. I would pick it up maybe for 10? But the gameplay itself is quite challenging fun and overall great. Yes there is a lot of repetition but the gameplay itself once mastered, should provide enough substance to beat the game within 20-40 hrs. Depending at how smart you are and luck of the draw sort of things. I had to restart over a few times before I figured out that you restart with your items. Once you own your shop you can get everything then the game becomes more or less a sandbox.Theres' still the dungeons, I almost have beatten the game. The game needs a sequel or a spinoff or something as it's not dull to buy sell buy sell. Once you understand the more complex economics (such as deflation.) You will make bank. I once made 8x an item. It'll become really fun. Some customers have lots of cash typically older crowds, but young girls won't have as much with some variables.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 6, 2012
												It's time for the noon rush and the price of candy has shot up 20%, the children will be coming in soon and you've just restocked your shop nventory from another succesful day of treasure hunting in the dungeons. Unlike in other RPGs where you're the hero who goes off adventuring and selling the sutff you find to shops, you're now the shopkeeper known as Recette, whose father has fled the country and left behind a giant debt that must be paid back in payments each week otherwise Recette will be kicked to the streets as her home is sold off.The bulk of Recettear involves studying the customers and the times they like to enter your store in order to stock the items they want to buy. As you become more succesful, your store expands, the quality of items and their prices increases and you start unlocking new adventurers to fight monsters.Recettear is a nice diversion but don't expect a deep engaging business magement simulator like Roller Coaster Tycoon, or Tropico.
